quizquestion.question: Select the synonym to “Frequency”.
quizquestion.explanation: Many refer to “Rate” as synonymous to Frequency, but according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task list, Frequency and Rate are separate measures. “Frequency” is synonymous with “Count”.

quizquestion.question: Frequency is:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A simple count of the total occurrences of behavior
wrongAnswer: The number of occurrences of the behavior across time
The amount of time from the discriminative stimulus to the occurrence of the behavior
The amount of time between occurrences of behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Many refer to “Rate” as synonymous to Frequency, but according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List, Frequency and Rate are separate measures. “Frequency” is synonymous with “Count”.

quizquestion.question: Select the example that uses the measure of frequency
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Robert called on his phone three times.
wrongAnswer: Robert called on his phone three times in one day.
Robert called on his phone every five minutes
Robert calls on his phone every day.
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is defined as a simple count of the total occurrences of behavior, which is different from Rate, according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List.

quizquestion.question: Select the example that uses the measure of frequency
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Jeff engaged in five angry outbursts.
wrongAnswer: Jeff engaged in angry outbursts frequently.
Jeff engaged in five angry outbursts per hour.
Jeff engaged in more angry outbursts today than he did yesterday.
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is defined as a simple count of the total occurrences of behavior, which is different from Rate, according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List.

quizquestion.question: Select the example that uses the measure of frequency
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Erin didn’t engage in any hand flapping.
wrongAnswer: Erin engaged in hand flapping for 3.5 minutes.
Erin engaged in hand flapping for 3.5 minutes during the last hour.
Erin engaged in hand flapping five times during a five minute session.
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is defined as a simple count of the total occurrences of behavior, which is different from Rate, according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List.

quizquestion.question: Select the word the means the same as “Count”
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is defined as a simple count of the total occurrences of behavior, which is different from Rate, according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List.

quizquestion.question: What was the frequency of Dylan’s physical aggression if he engaged in the behavior 2 times during a 10 minute session?
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is defined as a simple count of the total occurrences of behavior, which is different from Rate, according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List.

quizquestion.question: What was the frequency of Donald’s appropriate responses if he engaged in the behavior about once every hour during the day?
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is defined as a simple count of the total occurrences of behavior, which is different from Rate, according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List.

quizquestion.question: What was the frequency of the student’s “appropriate hand raising” behavior given she raised her hand twice per hour for the first hour, then none during the second hour?
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is defined as a simple count of the total occurrences of behavior, which is different from Rate, according to the BACB Fourth Edition Task List.

quizquestion.question: Frequency (Count) is usually a sufficient measure while creating and updating a behavior plan.
quizquestion.explanation: A count of the behavior is not very beneficial without the duration of the observation. Two occurrences of angry outbursts during five minutes of observation is very different from two occurrences of angry outbursts in four hours of observation. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Define “rate”
wrongAnswer: The amount of time the behavior lasts
The amount of time from the Sd to the response
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is defined as the number of responses per unit of time. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Frequency across time is referred to as
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is defined as the number of responses per unit of time. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Rate is an appropriate measure for which of the following behaviors:
wrongAnswer: Continuous behaviors (behaviors that last a long time)
quizquestion.explanation: Behaviors within discrete trials are not usually appropriate to measure with Rate because the antecedents are artificially contrived. Percent correct is usually a more appropriate measure, or trials-to-criterion. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Mary is a BCBA conducting discrete trials with an individual. She is targeting appropriate responses. What would be the best measure for Mary to use?
quizquestion.explanation: Behaviors within discrete trials are not usually appropriate to measure with Rate because the antecedents are artificially contrived. Percent correct is usually a more appropriate measure, or trials-to-criterion. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: John is a BCBA wanting to measure how often George engages in tongue clicking. What would be an appropriate measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is usually the best measure for free operant behaviors. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA observed her student engaging in typing during a 2 minute session. During that session, the student pressed 22 keys. What is the rate of key pressing observed by the BCBA?
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is defined as the number of responses per unit of time. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Rate is not an appropriate measure for which of the behaviors below?
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is generally not an appropriate measure for continuous behaviors (behaviors that have a long duration). Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Rate is measured using which measurable dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is based on the measurable dimension of behavior “Repeatability”. Repeatability states that instance of a response class can occur repeatedly through time. You can count behavior. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: The measurable dimension of behavior “repeatability” can be defined as:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Instances of behavior can occur repeatedly through time
wrongAnswer: Every instance of behavior occurs at a certain point in time
Behavior always repeats if it has happened before
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is based on the measurable dimension of behavior “Repeatability”. Repeatability states that instance of a response class can occur repeatedly through time. You can count behavior. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: What are the critical components of measuring rate of a behavior?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Count of the behavior AND Observation Time
wrongAnswer: Count of the behavior AND Duration of the behavior
Duration of the behavior AND Observation time
Duration of the behavior AND Latency of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is defined as the number of responses per unit of time. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Duration is based on which measurable dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is based on the measureable dimension of behavior “Temporal Extent”. Temporal extent explains that every instance of behavior occurs during some amount of time. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Temporal Extent is defined as:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Every instance of behavior occurs during some amount of time
wrongAnswer: Instances of behavior can occur repeatedly through time
Every instance of behavior occurs at a certain point in time
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is based on the measureable dimension of behavior “Temporal Extent”. Temporal extent explains that every instance of behavior occurs during some amount of time. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Appropriate units of measure to use when measuring duration include all but the following:
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is usually measured with seconds, minutes, or hours. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Define “duration” with regards to measuring behavior
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The amount of time in which behavior occurs
wrongAnswer: How many times the behavior occurred
The amount of time from the Sd to the beginning of the behavior.
Count of the behavior across time.
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is the amount of time in which behavior occurs. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: During a single session, Mary observed John engaging in angry outbursts for 2 minutes, then again for 3 minutes, then again for 2 minutes. What is the total duration of angry outbursts during that session?
quizquestion.explanation: Total duration per session is the duration of each occurrence of behavior during the session added together. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Jeremy engages in on task behavior for extended periods of time. Which measure would be most beneficial to use to measure this behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is usually the best measure for continuous behaviors. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: John is a BCBA wanting to measure how often George engages in tongue clicking. What would be an appropriate measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is usually the best measure for free operant behaviors. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Katy engages in isolation for hours at a time. What would be an appropriate measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is usually the best measure for continuous behaviors. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Fred engaged in 20 instances of yelling during a one hour observation. What was the total duration of the behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Total duration per session is the duration of each occurrence of behavior during the session added together. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Which type of behavior is most often measured by duration?
wrongAnswer: All types of behavior should be measured with duration
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is usually the best measure for continuous behaviors. Cooper, John O., Heron, Timothy E.Heward, William L.. (2007) Applied behavior analysis /Upper Saddle River, N.J. : Pearson/Merrill-Prentice Hall.

quizquestion.question: Latency is defined as:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The amount of time between the stimulus and the response
wrongAnswer: Amount of time in which a behavior occurs
The amount of time between two responses
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Latency is based on which dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is based on the dimension “Temporal Locus” Temporal locus refers to that behavior occurs at a certain point in time with respect to other events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Define Temporal Locus
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Behavior occurs at a certain point in time with respect to other events.
wrongAnswer: Behavior occurs during some amount of time
Behavior always occurs after an antecedent.
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is based on the dimension “Temporal Locus” Temporal locus refers to that behavior occurs at a certain point in time with respect to other events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: After 3.5 seconds of prompting Mary, she finally got up and placed her dishes in the dishwasher, which took her 6 seconds to complete. What is the latency of Mary complying with the prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: After 3.5 seconds of prompting Mary, she finally got up and placed her dishes in the dishwasher, which took her 6 seconds to complete. In this scenario 3.5 seconds refers to:
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: After 3.5 seconds of prompting Mary, she finally got up and placed her dishes in the dishwasher, which took her 6 seconds to complete. In this scenario 6 seconds refers to:
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The stoplight turned green. 1.2 seconds later James pressed the gas pedal. James pressed the gas pedal for 17 seconds until he saw a police car. .5  seconds after seeing the police car James pressed the brake pedal. What was the Latency of pushing the gas pedal?
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The stoplight turned green. 1.2 seconds later James pressed the gas pedal. James pressed the gas pedal for 17 seconds until he saw a police car. .5  seconds after seeing the police car James pressed the brake pedal. What was the Latency of pushing the brake pedal?
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The stoplight turned green. 1.2 seconds later James pressed the gas pedal. James pressed the gas pedal for 17 seconds until he saw a police car. .5  seconds after seeing the police car James pressed the brake pedal. What was the duration of pushing the gas pedal?
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: James pressed the brake pedal for 33 seconds. The stoplight turned green. 1.2 seconds later James pressed the gas pedal. James pressed the gas pedal for 17 seconds until he saw a police car. .5  seconds after seeing the police car James pressed the brake pedal for 3 seconds. What duration of pushing the brake pedal?
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is defined as the amount of time between the stimulus and the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Define Interresponse time (IRT)
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response.
wrongAnswer: The amount of time between the stimulus and the response
The amount of time in which behavior occurs
The Count of the behavior across time
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is the amount of time between the stimulus and the response?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: IRT is based on which dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is based on the dimension ”temporal locus”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Define Temporal Locus
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Behavior occurs at a certain point in time with respect to other events.
wrongAnswer: Behavior occurs during some amount of time
Behavior always occurs after an antecedent.
quizquestion.explanation: Temporal locus refers to that behavior occurs at a certain point in time with respect to other events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a session of observation, Rachel hits her head. 8 seconds later, she hits her head again. 3 seconds later she starts yelling which lasts for 30 seconds. 18 seconds later she yells again. What is the IRT of head hitting during this session?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a session of observation, Rachel hits her head. 8 seconds later, she hits her head again. 3 seconds later she starts yelling which lasts for 30 seconds. 18 seconds later she yells again. What is the IRT of yelling during this session?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a session of observation, Rachel hits her head. 8 seconds later, she hits her head again. 3 seconds later she starts yelling which lasts for 30 seconds. 18 seconds later she yells again for 20 seconds. What is the total duration of yelling?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a 3 minute session of observation, Rachel hits her head. 8 seconds later, she hits her head again. 3 seconds later she starts yelling which lasts for 30 seconds. 18 seconds later she yells again. There are no other problem behaviors during the session. What is the rate of head hitting?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: John puts a potato chip in his mouth. 3 seconds later he does it again. 4 seconds later he does it again. And finally, 2 seconds later he does it one last time. What is the average Interresponse time between these 4 instances of chip consumption?
quizquestion.explanation: IRT is defined as the amount of time that occurs between two consecutive instances of a response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Define percent of occurrence
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration)
wrongAnswer: Amount of time between two consecutive responses
Time between the stimulus and the initiation of a response
A measure of how response rates change over time
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Calculate the percent of occurrence of completed tasks for John. He was prompted to complete 20 different tasks and refused only 3 times. He complied following all other prompts.
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary (BCBA) conducted discrete trials in which she gave her client 10 opportunities to make a correct response. The individual made 8 correct responses. What is the percent of correct responses made?
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which dimension of behavior is used when reporting a percentage?
quizquestion.explanation: Percentages use ratios of the same dimensional quantity. The dimensional quantity is canceled out in the ratio equation and no longer contains those dimensional quantities. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The following is a list of the amount of hours Jason has slept the past 10 days: 8, 6.5, 9, 7, 9, 10.5, 6, 8, 7, 7.5. What is the percent of nights Jason slept at least 8 hours?
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The BCBA observed her student over 20 sessions. During those sessions, the BCBA observed physical aggression in 60% of sessions. How many occurrences of physical aggression did the BCBA observe?
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The BCBA conducted a trial based functional analysis. The client engaged in hand flapping during 7 of the 10 alone sessions. What percent of occurrence is this?
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jim used 10 second whole interval recording to measure angry outbursts across 20 intervals. The individual engaged in angry outbursts during 4 entire intervals. What percent of occurrence of angry outbursts was observed?
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When would it be appropriate to use the measure “percent of occurrence”
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Correct responses in a discrete trial
wrongAnswer: Continuous behavior with a long duration
Measuring free operants in a natural environment
When you need to determine the amount of time elapsed between two behaviors.
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are testing for behavioral contrast between John’s behavior at home and at school. John engaged in disruptive behavior 4/5 days at school and 1/5 at home. What is the percent of occurrence of disruptive behavior at school and home?
quizquestion.explanation: Percent of occurrence is defined as a ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities (i.e., Duration ÷ Duration). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Define trials to criterion
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance
wrongAnswer: A ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities
The amount of time between two consecutive responses
The amount of time from the stimulus to the response
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is one of the uses of collecting trials to criterion data?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: For the BCBA to look back at the “cost” of treatment
wrongAnswer: To make function based decisions in your behavior program
For the learner to see their own progress
To see the frequency of problem behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Define trials to criterion
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance
wrongAnswer: A ratio formed by combining the same dimensional quantities
The amount of time between two consecutive responses
The amount of time from the stimulus to the response
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When using trials to criterion, you measure the amount of “trials” it takes for the learner to reach a set level of performance. Which of the following is NOT an example of a trial?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The number of occurrences of disruptive behavior
wrongAnswer: Each attempt at tying his shoe
A block of 10 opportunities for the learner to discriminate letter pronunciation
Each attempt at identifying the written word “cat”
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You want to measure how long it takes your client to learn how to put on his pants independently. What would be an appropriate measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. Trials to Criterion is used to measure how many attempts it took the learner to achieve the level of performance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You want to measure how often your client puts his pants on independently. What would be an appropriate measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. Trials to Criterion is used to measure how many attempts it took the learner to achieve the level of performance.  (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: It took John 7 trials to count to 5. What can the behavior analyst get from these data?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The BCBA “spent” 7 trials to teach this skill.
wrongAnswer: John will take less than 7 additional trials to count to 10
John will take 7 additional trials to count to 10
John will take more than 7 additional trials to count to 10
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: It took John 7 trials to count to 5, 5 additional trials to count to 10, and only 3 additional trials to count to 15. What can the behavior analyst get from these data?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: John is increasingly acquiring skills related to numbers and counting
wrongAnswer: John will count to 20 in only 1 trial
John is learning too quickly and will likely forget how to count later on
The BCBA “spent” 18 trials to teach this skill
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When would it NOT be appropriate to use trials to criterion?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: You are determining which behavior of concern to address
wrongAnswer: It is important to identify if the speed at which the learner is progressing is accelerating
The behavior analyst wants to determine the “cost” of the progress
The learner’s parents ask how quickly their child is learning
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion will not help determine which behavior of concern to address. The other situations are all appropriate examples of using trials to criterion. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is one of the uses of collecting trials to criterion data?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: To determine if the learner’s progress is accelerating
wrongAnswer: To make function based decisions in your behavior program
For the learner to see their own progress
To see the frequency of problem behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Trials to criterion is defined as the number of response opportunities needed to achieve a predetermined level of performance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT a purpose of collecting IOA?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: To determine if the behavior plan is being followed
wrongAnswer: To determine the competence of new observers
To increase confidence in your behavior definitions
quizquestion.explanation: all of these are benefits of IOA except for determining if a behavior plan is being run. That is a purpose of running a treatment integrity check.

quizquestion.question: Identify the formula to calculate Total Count IOA.
wrongAnswer: (int 1 IOA + Int 2 IOA + Int N IOA)/ n intervals   x 100
(Number of intervals of 100% IOA)/n intervals  x 100
Number of trials agreement/total number of trials  x 100
quizquestion.explanation: The formula to calculate Total Count IOA is (Smaller count/Larger count) x 100. This is the simplest method, however is not always appropriate to use.

quizquestion.question: Identify the formula to calculate Exact Count-per Interval IOA
quizquestion.correctAnswer: (Number of intervals of 100% IOA)/n intervals  x 100
wrongAnswer: (int 1 IOA + Int 2 IOA + Int N IOA)/ n intervals   x 100
Number of trials agreement/total number of trials  x 100
quizquestion.explanation: The formula to calculate Exact Count-per Interval IOA is (Number of intervals of 100% IOA)/n intervals  x 100.

quizquestion.question: Identify the formula to calculate Trial-by-Trial IOA.
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Number of trials agreement/total number of trials  x 100
wrongAnswer: (int 1 IOA + Int 2 IOA + Int N IOA)/ n intervals   x 100
(Number of intervals of 100% IOA)/n intervals  x 100
quizquestion.explanation: The formula to calculate Trial-by-Trial IOA is Number of trials agreement/total number of trials  x 100.

quizquestion.question: Calculate the Total Count IOA for Interval 5 from the table:
quizquestion.explanation: The formula to calculate Total Count IOA is (Smaller count/Larger count) x 100. This is the simplest method, however is not always appropriate to use.

quizquestion.question: Calculate the Exact Count-per-Interval IOA from the table:
quizquestion.explanation: The formula to calculate Exact Count-per Interval IOA is (Number of intervals of 100% IOA)/n intervals  x 100. In this example interval 2, 3, and 4 have 100% total count IOA. So (3 intervals/5 intervals) x100 = 60%.

quizquestion.question: Which method of calculating IOA would be appropriate for the data below?
quizquestion.explanation: Trial-by-trial IOA would be most appropriate because we are measuring the occurrence or non-occurrence of behavior. There are only two options each trial: “yes” or “no”.

quizquestion.question: Calculate the trial-by-trial IOA from the data below.
quizquestion.explanation: The formula to calculate Trial-by-Trial IOA is Number of trials agreement/total number of trials  x 100.

quizquestion.question: During a session of observing behavior, observer 1 measured 18 occurrences of problem behavior. Observer 2 measured 20 occurrences of problem behavior. To calculate IOA for this session, which IOA measure should be used?
quizquestion.explanation: Total count IOA can be used to measure IOA of two observers during a single session.

quizquestion.question: During a session of observing behavior, observer 1 measured 18 occurrences of problem behavior. Observer 2 measured 20 occurrences of problem behavior. Calculate the total count IOA for this session.
quizquestion.explanation: The formula to calculate Total Count IOA is (Smaller count/Larger count) x 100.

phase.name: Evaluate the accuracy and reliability of measurement procedures

quizquestion.question: With regards to behavior analytic measurement procedures, reliability refers to
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest
wrongAnswer: The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value
The extent to which the measured value is believable
The extent to which the behavior is affected by those observing the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Reliability is defined as “The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: With regards to behavior analytic measurement procedures, accuracy refers to
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value
wrongAnswer: The extent to which the measured value is believable
The extent to which the behavior is affected by those observing the behavior
The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest
quizquestion.explanation: Accuracy is defined as “The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Cassidy steps on the scale and weighs 125lbs. She steps off, then back on and it says exactly 125lbs again. Cassidy actually weighs 130lbs. The scale demonstrates:
quizquestion.explanation: Reliability is defined as “The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest”. Accuracy is defined as “The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Cassidy steps on the scale and weighs 125lbs. She steps off and back on and weighs 130lbs. This scale demonstrates:
quizquestion.explanation: Reliability is defined as “The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest”. Accuracy is defined as “The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary is a BCBA working with a client who engages in elopement. Mary has two RBTs collecting data. The two RBT’s typically have the same score, however Mary is concerned that the data is truly reflective of what is happening with her client. What should Mary do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Conduct an accuracy assessment on the measure of elopement
wrongAnswer: Implement corrective action on the RBT’s so they collect more accurate data
Praise the RBT’s for good data collection practices, and ask them to do a little bit better
quizquestion.explanation: An accuracy assessment can be collected to determine if the data collected is truly reflective of what is happening. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary is a BCBA and has a RBT collecting data on a client engaging in elopement. Mary suspects the RBT to be making up data, but isn’t sure. What should Mary do?
wrongAnswer: Implement corrective action on the RBT’s so they collect more accurate data
Praise the RBT’s for good data collection practices, and ask them to do a little bit better
Conduct an accuracy assessment on the measure of elopement
quizquestion.explanation: IOA should be calculated regularly to ensure the data is reliable. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Observer I measured the occurrences of angry outbursts to be 12 during the session. Observer II also measured 12. After reviewing a recording of the session the BCBA finds the true value of angry outbursts to be 18. The data reported indicate the measure to be:
quizquestion.explanation: Reliability is defined as “The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest”. Accuracy is defined as “The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Observer I measured the occurrences of angry outbursts to be 12 during the session. Observer II also measured 12. After reviewing a recording of the session the BCBA finds the true value of angry outbursts to be 12. The data reported indicate the measure to be:
quizquestion.explanation: Reliability is defined as “The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest”. Accuracy is defined as “The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Inter-Observer Agreement measures:
quizquestion.explanation: Reliability is defined as “The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest”. Accuracy is defined as “The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: If a measure is not reliable, can the measure be accurate?
quizquestion.explanation: Reliability is defined as “The extent to which a measurement procedure produces the same value when repeatedly contacting the behavior of interest”. Accuracy is defined as “The extent to which the measurement corresponds to the true value”. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Design, plot, and interpret data using equal-interval graphs

quizquestion.question: What is the most commonly used graphic display used by behavior analysts?
quizquestion.explanation: Line graphs are most commonly used. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows for data to be displayed between two dimensions (e.g., frequency of behavior across time). Each data point is connect to the next with a line.
quizquestion.explanation: Line graphs allow for data to be displayed between two dimensions (e.g., frequency of behavior across time). Each data point is connect to the next with a line. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This graph is also referred to as a histogram
quizquestion.explanation: The bar graph is also called a histogram. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows you to display and compare discrete sets of data that are not related to one another by a common underlying dimension by which the horizontal axis can be scaled.
quizquestion.explanation: The bar graph allows you to display and compare discrete sets of data that are not related to one another by a common underlying dimension by which the horizontal axis can be scaled. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected.
quizquestion.explanation: The scatterplot shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows you to discover the temporal distribution of a target behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: The scatterplot shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What kind of graph is this?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of a scatterplot.

quizquestion.question: What kind of graph is this?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of a line graph.

quizquestion.question: Which axis is the x axis (or abscissa)?
quizquestion.explanation: The x axis is also known as the horizontal axis, or abscissa. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which axis is the y axis (or ordinate)?
quizquestion.explanation: The y axis is the vertical axis, or ordinate. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Design plot and interpret data using a cumulative record to display data.

quizquestion.question: This type of graph was developed by Skinner to collect data in the experimental analysis of behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: The cumulative record was developed by Skinner. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph displays the total number of responses emitted during a single session of observation.
quizquestion.explanation: The cumulative record displays the total number of responses emitted during a single session of observation. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a semilogarithmic chart?
quizquestion.explanation: The standard celeration chart is a semilogarithmic chart. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph is used to display behaviors that are accelerating or decelerating in rate. The vertical axis displays frequency at increasing and non-proportional increments.
quizquestion.explanation: The standard celeration chart is used to display behaviors that are accelerating or decelerating in rate. The vertical axis displays frequency at increasing and non-proportional increments. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In this cumulative record, what is likely measured across the x axis?
wrongAnswer: Total frequency of the target behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Sessions is likely recorded along the x axis (horizontal axis)

quizquestion.question: In this cumulative record, what is likely measured across the y axis?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Total frequency of the target behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Total frequency of the target behavior is the likely measured along the y axis (vertical axis).

quizquestion.question: In a cumulative record, what is indicated by a steeper slope?
quizquestion.explanation: In a cumulative record, the steeper the slope, the higher the response rate.

quizquestion.question: Which axis is the x axis (or abscissa)?
quizquestion.explanation: The x axis is also known as the horizontal axis, or abscissa. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which axis is the y axis (or ordinate)?
quizquestion.explanation: The y axis is the vertical axis, or ordinate. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which measure is typically used while graphing on a cumulative record?
quizquestion.explanation: Frequency is typically used while graphing on a cumulative record.

phase.name: Design and implement continuous measurement procedures

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a continuous measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording and Timing are common procedures used when collecting continuous measurement data. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a continuous measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording and Timing are common procedures used when collecting continuous measurement data. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Wrist counters, hand-tally digital counters, tally marks, are all devices that can be used with which measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Wrist counters, digital counters, or simple tally marks on paper can all be used with event recording procedures. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Stopwatches/timers are necessary for which measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Timing measurement procedures require a device to track time for accurate time measures. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jacob engages in hand clapping frequently, but it is easy to distinguish one instance of the behavior from another. Which measurement procedure should you use?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording should be used to measure frequency of behavior if one instance of the behavior is distinguishable from another. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jacob engages in hand clapping frequently, and it is difficult to distinguish one instance of the behavior from another. Which measurement procedure should you use?
quizquestion.explanation: Whole-interval recording is a discontinuous measurement procedure best used when one instance of behavior is not distinguishable from another. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Alice engages in episodes of screaming. You want to measure continuous duration of this behavior. Which measurement procedure do you use?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording and Timing are common procedures used when collecting continuous measurement data. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is measured using Event Recording procedures only?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording is used to measure frequency of behavior. Timing is used to measure duration, latency, and IRT. Both procedures are used in measuring Rate of behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What can be measured using Timing procedures only?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording is used to measure frequency of behavior. Timing is used to measure duration, latency, and IRT. Both procedures are used in measuring Rate of behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What can be measured using both Event Recording and Timing procedures?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording is used to measure frequency of behavior. Timing is used to measure duration, latency, and IRT. Both procedures are used in measuring Rate of behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Design and implement discontinuous measurement procedures

quizquestion.question: All of the following are discontinuous measurement procedures EXCEPT:
quizquestion.explanation: Discontinuous measurement procedures do not require constant measurement of behavior, rather behavior is observed in intervals, measuring occurrence or non-occurrence of behavior. This includes partial interval and whole interval recording, as well as momentary time sampling, and PLACHECK. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this discontinuous measurement procedure the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs during the entire session observed.
quizquestion.explanation: Whole Interval Recording is when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs during the entire session observed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this discontinuous measurement procedure, the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs at all during the entire session observed.
quizquestion.explanation: Partial interval recording occurs when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs at all during the entire session. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this discontinuous measurement procedure, the observer marks “yes” if the behavior was occurring at the end of the interval.
quizquestion.explanation: Momentary time sampling occurs when the observer marks “yes” if the behavior was occurring at the end of the interval. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this discontinuous measurement procedure, the teacher momentarily observes a group of students and records the amount of children engaging in the behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Planned Activity Check (PLACHECK) occurs when the teacher momentarily observes a group of students and records the amount of children engaging in the behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this discontinuous measurement procedure, the observer marks “no” if the behavior does not occur throughout the entire session.
quizquestion.explanation: Whole Interval Recording is when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs during the entire session observed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During this discontinuous measurement procedure, the observer marks “no” if the behavior did not occur at all during the session. If there were any occurrences they mark “yes”.
quizquestion.explanation: Partial interval recording occurs when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs at all during the entire session. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a 10 second interval, Ruby engages in disruptive behavior twice for 5 seconds total duration. Using a whole interval recording procedure, what would be marked on the data sheet?
quizquestion.explanation: Whole Interval Recording is when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs during the entire session observed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a 10 second interval, Ruby engages in disruptive behavior twice for 5 seconds total duration. Using a partial interval recording procedure, what would be marked on the data sheet?
quizquestion.explanation: Partial interval recording occurs when the observer marks “yes” when the behavior occurs at all during the entire session. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Ruby engaged in disruptive behavior for 9 seconds, but stopped right before the end of the 10 second interval. Using a momentary time sampling at the end of the 10 second interval, what would be marked on the data sheet?
quizquestion.explanation: Momentary time sampling occurs when the observer marks “yes” if the behavior was occurring at the end of the interval. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Stimulus Preference Assessments are used to identify:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus preference assessments are used to identify preferred (appetitive) stimuli. Appetitive stimuli are not always reinforcers.

quizquestion.question: All of the following are trial based methods for determining preferred stimuli EXCEPT:
quizquestion.explanation: Free operant observation can be used to determine preferred stimuli, but it is not trial based. Single stimulus, paired stimuli, and multiple stimuli are all trial based methods.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, stimuli are measure consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.
quizquestion.explanation: A single stimulus preference assessment is used by presenting stimuli consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents a stuffed toy and measures how long the individual interacts with the toy. The BCBA removes the stuffed toy and presents a backpack and measures the interaction with the item. The BCBA removes the backpack and presents a spinner toy. What type of preference is the BCBA conducting?
quizquestion.explanation: A single stimulus preference assessment is used by presenting stimuli consecutively, one at a time, and the interaction with the stimulus is recorded by the observer. Each stimulus is presented more than once, but the order is varied.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, 2 stimuli are presented to the individual, creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.
quizquestion.explanation: A paired stimuli preference assessment is conducted by presenting 2 stimuli to the individual creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents the child with a stuffed toy and a fidget spinner, and the child selects the fidget spinner. The BCBA then presents a fidget spinner and a backpack, and the child selects the fidget spinner. This is done repeatedly, varying the pairing of items. What type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A paired stimuli preference assessment is conducted by presenting 2 stimuli to the individual creating a forced choice of one of the stimuli. This is done repeatedly with multiple items, ending with every stimulus being paired with each of the other stimuli.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, an array of items (3 or more) is presented to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents 6 items to the child and says “Choose one”. The child selects an item, and then shortly after, the BCBA places the item back into the array of items. The BCBA says “choose one” again. Which type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then placed back into the array and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is usually done repeatedly until all items have been selected.

quizquestion.question: During this preference assessment, an array of items (3 or more) is presented to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.

quizquestion.question: The BCBA presents 6 items to the child and says “Choose one”. The child selects an item, and then shortly after, the BCBA removes that item from sight. The BCBA says “choose one” again with only the remaining 5 items displayed. Which type of preference assessment is being conducted?
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple stimuli with replacement preference assessment is conducted by presenting an array of items (3 or more) to the individual. The individual selects an item. The item is then removed from sight, and the individual is again prompted to select an item. This is done repeatedly until all items from the array have been selected.

phase.name: Use the dimensions of ABA to evaluate whether interventions are behavior analytic in nature

quizquestion.question: Sally is a BCBA and decides to show her client’s parents what ABA is capable of. She teaches the child to walk in circles with the child’s hands behind his back. This behavior has no socially acceptable purpose, and was trained entirely to impress the parents. What dimension of ABA is Sally violating?
quizquestion.explanation: Applied refers to the behaviors behavior analysts address. Behavior analysts should address behaviors which have a socially significant change in the individual’s life. In the example above, the behavior analyst addresses a behavior that will not positively affect the person’s life. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: Jake creates a behavior intervention plan and addresses “Angry Outbursts” in the plan. His definition for Angry Outbursts states “Defined as whenever Yolanda gets upset”. Which dimension of behavior is Jake violating?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral refers to a couple things. First, behavior needs to be measurable. The observers need to know when the behavior happens with clear behavioral definitions. Second, we study behavior, not about behavior. If we want to improve behavior of an individual, we look at the specific behavior and the environment, not indirect measures such as questionnaires. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: The BCBA wants to find out why a client is engaging in problem behavior. The BCBA distributes a questionnaire about the individual’s mood. He determines that the client is engaging in the problem behavior because the client’s mood is frequently poor. This violates which dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral refers to a couple things. First, behavior needs to be measurable. The observers need to know when the behavior happens with clear behavioral definitions. Second, we study behavior, not about behavior. If we want to improve behavior of an individual, we look at the specific behavior and the environment, not indirect measures such as questionnaires. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: Melanie measured the occurrences of her client’s tantrum behavior in baseline. She then implemented an intervention, and shortly after returned to baseline. She was able to determine the intervention’s effect on the client’s tantrum behavior. Melanie exemplified which dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Analytic refers to the need for behavior analysts to determine a functional relationship between the intervention and change in the targeted behavior. A simple report that things are improving isn’t good enough for behavior analysts. Demonstrating that the intervention helped improve the behavior is necessary. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: John is a BCBA that just received a new client. The new client received services prior and already had a behavior intervention plan in place. John was able to read his prior behavior plan and know completely what interventions were being run before, to the extent he could replicate the interventions. This demonstrates which dimension of ABA?
quizquestion.explanation: Technological refers to the need for behavior analysts to operate under sufficient detail to where the interventions would be able to be replicated with the same results. Detail and clarity is essential for this to take place. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: Jared is a BCBA and decides to implement a strategy known as “Astronaut Training”. This involves having the child sit in a rotating chair while playing space sound effects. Jared states that he does this because he heard it’s an effective treatment for Autism, even though it doesn’t use the basics of behavior analysis. Jared is violating which dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Conceptually systematic refers to the behavior analyst’s need to be grounded in the well-researched basics of ABA including reinforcement and punishment. Our interventions shouldn’t stray from these technologies, even when applying them differently. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: With ABA strategies, Amy was able to improve greatly in the frequency of appropriate questions in the classroom. She is asking questions applicable to the learning content, and is not asking distracting questions. Which dimension of ABA is evident?
quizquestion.explanation: Effective refers to the behavior analyst’s drive for effective interventions. Our interventions should lead toward progress. Behavior analysts continue to implement interventions until the behavior is occurring at the desired level of performance. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: Ted received behavior analytic services, addressing his cursing behavior. These services were terminated 3 months ago after reaching his goals. Ted continues to not curs and is frequently making appropriate comments. Which dimension of ABA is evident?
quizquestion.explanation: Generality refers to behavior change that lasts over time, that appears in novel environments, or leads to other untrained improved behavior. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: Susan learned how to write her name while at her school desk with a pencil. Her mom notices her independently writing her name at home with crayons. Which dimension of ABA is evident?
quizquestion.explanation: Generality refers to behavior change that lasts over time, that appears in novel environments, or leads to other untrained improved behavior. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

quizquestion.question: Adam wrote a behavior support plan and included an immense amount of detail on how to implement the interventions. This is an example of which dimension of ABA?
quizquestion.explanation: Technological refers to the need for behavior analysts to operate under sufficient detail to where the interventions would be able to be replicated with the same results. Detail and clarity is essential for this to take place. (Baer, Wolf, & Risley, 1968)

phase.name: Review and interpret articles from the behavior-analytic literature

quizquestion.question: Jerry conducts research, and his study concludes that the intervention had a positive effect on behavior. This turned out to be false, and a misinterpretation of the data. What kind of error is this?
quizquestion.explanation: Type I error (false positive) is made when the researcher concludes that the independent variable had an effect on the dependent variable, with no such relation occurs in nature. Type II error (false negative) is made when the researcher concludes that the independently did not have an effect on the dependent variable, when in fact it did. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jerry conducts research, and his study concludes that the intervention did not have an effect on behavior. This turned out to be false, and a misinterpretation of the data. The intervention did in fact have an effect on the behavior. What kind of error is this?
quizquestion.explanation: Type I error (false positive) is made when the researcher concludes that the independent variable had an effect on the dependent variable, with no such relation occurs in nature. Type II error (false negative) is made when the researcher concludes that the independently did not have an effect on the dependent variable, when in fact it did. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of error is also known as a false positive. They report a functional relation between the independent and dependent variables, when there actually is not one.
quizquestion.explanation: Type I error (false positive) is made when the researcher concludes that the independent variable had an effect on the dependent variable, with no such relation occurs in nature. Type II error (false negative) is made when the researcher concludes that the independently did not have an effect on the dependent variable, when in fact it did. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of error is also known as a false negative. They report no functional relation between the independent and dependent variables, when one actually occurred.
quizquestion.explanation: Type I error (false positive) is made when the researcher concludes that the independent variable had an effect on the dependent variable, with no such relation occurs in nature. Type II error (false negative) is made when the researcher concludes that the independently did not have an effect on the dependent variable, when in fact it did. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which type of error occurs most frequently in behavior-analytic literature?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts use visual inspection to interpret data and graphs. This results in an increased commission of type II errors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is the most common, and most recommended method for interpreting data for behavior analysts?
quizquestion.explanation: Visual inspection is the most common and most recommended method for interpreting data. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of validity refers to the extent to which the study shows that the changes to the independent variable were due to the dependent variable, as opposed to other uncontrolled variables.
quizquestion.explanation: Internal validity refers to the extent to which the study shows that the changes to the independent variable were due to the dependent variable, as opposed to other uncontrolled variables. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of validity refers to the extent to which the changes made to the behavior were significant to the individual. The interventions used were humane and culturally accepted.
quizquestion.explanation: Social validity refers to the extent to which the changes made to the behavior were significant to the individual. The interventions used were humane and culturally accepted. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of validity refers to the degree to which the findings from the study have generalized to other behaviors, settings, and/or subjects.
quizquestion.explanation: External validity refers to the degree to which the findings from the study have generalized to other behaviors, settings, and/or subjects. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What process needs to occur for research findings to have external validity
quizquestion.explanation: Replication of research findings needs to occur for the research findings to have external validity. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Systematically arrange independent variables to demonstrate their effects on dependent variables

quizquestion.question: In behavior analytic experiments, this variable is typically the behavior of interest.
quizquestion.explanation: The dependent variable in an experiment is used to determine if it changes “dependent” on the independent variable. It’s usually a target behavior in behavior analytic research. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In behavior analytic experiments, this variable is usually the intervention implemented.
quizquestion.explanation: The independent variable in an experiment is used to determine if it affects the dependent variable. In behavior analytic research it is typically the intervention. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In behavior analytic experiments, this type of variable are those stimuli the researchers take in to account and hold to a constant as to not interfere with the integrity of the study.
quizquestion.explanation: Extraneous variables are those stimuli the researchers take in to account and hold to a constant as to not interfere with the integrity of the study. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In behavior analytic experiments, this type of variable are those stimuli that haven’t been controlled for, and are suspected to have influence on the dependent variable.
quizquestion.explanation: Confounding variables are those stimuli that haven’t been controlled for, and are suspected to have influence on the dependent variable. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Albert wants to determine if implementing a DRA procedure will decrease the occurrences of yelling for his client. The DRA procedure is a
quizquestion.explanation: The independent variable in an experiment is used to determine if it affects the dependent variable. In behavior analytic research it is typically the intervention. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Albert wants to determine if implementing a DRA procedure will decrease the occurrences of yelling for his client. In this study, the occurrences of yelling are the
quizquestion.explanation: The dependent variable in an experiment is used to determine if it changes “dependent” on the independent variable. It’s usually a target behavior in behavior analytic research. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jeff conducted a study, and found that providing immediate and positive feedback to his employee resulted in increased work performance. In this study, work performance is the
quizquestion.explanation: The dependent variable in an experiment is used to determine if it changes “dependent” on the independent variable. It’s usually a target behavior in behavior analytic research. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jeff conducted a study, and found that providing immediate and positive feedback to his employee resulted in increased work performance. In this study, delivering immediate and positive feedback is the
quizquestion.explanation: The independent variable in an experiment is used to determine if it affects the dependent variable. In behavior analytic research it is typically the intervention. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jeff conducted a study, and found that providing immediate and positive feedback to his employee resulted in increased work performance. However, at the same time the employee was given a raise, which may have impacted his performance as well. In this study, the raise given to the employee is a
quizquestion.explanation: Confounding variables are those stimuli that haven’t been controlled for, and are suspected to have influence on the dependent variable. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jeff conducted a study, and found that providing immediate and positive feedback to his employee resulted in increased work performance. Before conducting the study, Jeff made sure that the employee wouldn’t be getting a raise, and ensured the employee’s environment would remain consistent throughout the study including lighting, temperature, and noise level. These stimuli being accounted for are:
quizquestion.explanation: Extraneous variables are those stimuli the researchers take in to account and hold to a constant as to not interfere with the integrity of the study. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is another name for the withdrawal experimental design?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are names to this experimental design.  (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is another name for the withdrawal experimental design?
quizquestion.explanation: Reversal is another name for the withdrawal experimental design. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When conducting an A-B-A reversal design, how many data points at a minimum should be present before moving from baseline to treatment?
quizquestion.explanation: At least 3 data points are required to constitute a trend. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In an A-B-A reversal design, what does “A” stand for?
quizquestion.explanation: the “A” phases are baseline phases. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Why is an A-B-A-B design better than A-B-A design
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Reintroducing treatment phase replicates the treatment effects, strengthening the demonstration of experimental control.
wrongAnswer: The longer the study, the more reliable it is.
It enables the learner to better discriminate different phases
It Baseline phase is critical to the demonstration of control
quizquestion.explanation: Reintroducing treatment phase replicates the treatment effects, strengthening the demonstration of experimental control. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is generally the most straightforward and powerful within-subject design for demonstrating a functional relation between an environmental manipulation and a behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: A-B-A-B design is generally the most straightforward and powerful within-subject design for demonstrating a functional relation between an environmental manipulation and a behavior.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: A-B-A design. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What effect did treatment have on the target behavior according to this graph?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The treatment increased the target behavior
wrongAnswer: The treatment decreased the target behavior
The treatment had no effect on the target behavior
Cannot be determined with this graph.
quizquestion.explanation: The treatment increased the target behavior.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an A-B-A-B design.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an alternating treatments design.

quizquestion.question: Which treatment design excels at comparing multiple treatments to determine which is most effective?
quizquestion.explanation: Alternating treatments design excels at comparing multiple treatments to determine which is most effective. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Describe the results from treatment A depicted as the yellow data path.
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Resulted in an increasing trend, ending higher than all other treatments.
wrongAnswer: Resulted in a decreasing trend, ending lower than all other treatments.
Averaged the highest level of target behavior with zero trend
Averaged lowest level of target behavior with zero trend.
quizquestion.explanation: Treatment A resulted in an increasing trend, ending higher than all other treatments.

quizquestion.question: Describe the results from treatment B depicted as the Red data path.
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Averaged the highest level of target behavior with zero trend
wrongAnswer: Averaged lowest level of target behavior with zero trend.
Resulted in an increasing trend, ending higher than all other treatments.
Resulted in a decreasing trend, ending lower than all other treatments.
quizquestion.explanation: Treatment B averaged the highest level of target behavior with zero trend.

quizquestion.question: Describe the results from treatment C depicted as the gray data path.
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Averaged lowest level of target behavior with zero trend.
wrongAnswer: Resulted in an increasing trend, ending higher than all other treatments.
Averaged the highest level of target behavior with zero trend
Resulted in a decreasing trend, ending lower than all other treatments.
quizquestion.explanation: Treatment C averaged the lowest level of target behavior with zero trend.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a possible variation to the alternating treatments design?
wrongAnswer: Single-phase alternating treatments design without a no-treatment control condition
Single-phase design in which two or more conditions are alternated
Two-phase design consisting of an initial baseline phase followed by a phase with two or more treatments
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are possible variations.

quizquestion.question: What effect did treatment have on the target behavior according to this graph?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The treatment increased the target behavior
wrongAnswer: The treatment decreased the target behavior
The treatment had no effect on the target behavior
Cannot be determined with this graph.
quizquestion.explanation: The treatment increased the target behavior.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an A-B-A-B design.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an alternating treatments design.

quizquestion.question: How many treatments is the minimum amount to be tested in an alternating treatments design?
quizquestion.explanation: 2 treatments is the minimum amount of treatments to be tested. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an advantage to the alternating treatments design?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are advantages. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design is used, when the treatment is applied in a stepwise fashion to  a single behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Changing criterion design should be used when the treatment is applied in a stepwise fashion to a single behavior?

quizquestion.question: Which of the following behaviors would benefit from a changing criterion experimental design?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Slowly increasing the amount of ounces the learner drinks by setting a reward for 8 ounces. Once the learner responds at a steady rate increase to 16, 24, 32, and finally 40 oz.
wrongAnswer: Increasing the rate of appropriate questions by using a reward program.
Comparing the effects of two different treatments to determine which is the most effective.
quizquestion.explanation: Slowly increasing the amount of ounces the learner drinks by setting a reward for 8 ounces. Once the learner responds at a steady rate increase to 16, 24, 32, and finally 40 oz.

quizquestion.question: What criterion is set during the initial baseline phase of a changing criterion design?
wrongAnswer: It depends on the individual circumstances
quizquestion.explanation: No criterion is set during the initial baseline phase.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an advantage of the changing criterion design?
wrongAnswer: It does not require a withdrawal or reversal
It enables an experimental analysis within the context of a gradually improving behavior, thus complementing the practice of many teachers
It is an effective design to demonstrate experimental control in many circumstances.
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are correct.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an advantage of the changing criterion design?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: It does not require a withdrawal or reversal
wrongAnswer: The target behavior must already be in the subject’s repertoire.
