Incorporating necessary features of the design may impede optimal learning rates.
quizquestion.explanation: It does not require a withdrawal or reversal

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a disadvantage of the changing criterion design?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The behavior must already be in the subject’s repertoire
wrongAnswer: It does not require a withdrawal or reversal
It enables an experimental analysis within the context of a gradually improving behavior, thus complementing the practice of many teachers
quizquestion.explanation: One disadvantage is that the behavior must already be in the subject’s repertoire.

quizquestion.question: In this graph, what do the horizontal lines going through the data points represent?
quizquestion.explanation: The horizontal lines represent the set criterion.

quizquestion.question: In this graph, why does the second to last data set decrease substantially, and then increase during the last data set?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Conducting this optional reversal design strengthens the experimental control in that the behavior followed the set criterion when it was increased as well as decreased.
wrongAnswer: It was likely a treatment error.
quizquestion.explanation: Conducting this optional reversal design strengthens the experimental control in that the behavior followed the set criterion when it was increased as well as decreased.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: Changing criterion design is depicted.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an alternating treatments design.

quizquestion.question: What is a variation of the multiple baseline design?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are variations of the multiple baseline design. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the multiple baseline design.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the delayed multiple baseline design.

quizquestion.question: What type of multiple baseline design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This graph depicts the multiple baseline across behaviors

quizquestion.question: When might the multiple baseline design be more appropriate to use over the reversal design?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: When the target behavior is likely to be irreversible
wrongAnswer: The multiple baseline design is always more appropriate
When reversing conditions is easily done
When you are measuring the effects of multiple treatments
quizquestion.explanation: It is appropriate to use the multiple baseline design over the reversal design when the target behavior is likely to be irreversible or when it is undesirable, impractical, or unethical to reverse conditions. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When might the multiple baseline design be more appropriate to use over the reversal design?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: When it is undesirable, impractical, or unethical to reverse conditions
wrongAnswer: The multiple baseline design is always more appropriate
When you are measuring the effects of multiple treatments
When the target behavior is easily reversible
quizquestion.explanation: It is appropriate to use the multiple baseline design over the reversal design when the target behavior is likely to be irreversible or when it is undesirable, impractical, or unethical to reverse conditions. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In a multiple baseline design, once stable responding is achieved in the baseline, what can you predict about subsequent sessions assuming the environment remains constant and no treatment is implemented?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: It would remain at current levels
wrongAnswer: It would increase or decrease depending on the treatment effects
quizquestion.explanation: Baseline assumes that responding would maintain at that level if the environment were to remain constant. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are implementing a multiple baseline across three subjects. Your first subject moves from baseline to treatment phase. Which phase should the second and third subjects be in during the first three sessions of treatment for subject 1?
quizquestion.explanation: Subjects 2 and 3 should be in baseline phase. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are implementing a multiple baseline across three subjects. Your second subject moves from baseline to treatment phase. Which phase should the First subject be in during the first three sessions of treatment for the second subject?
quizquestion.explanation: The first subject should be in treatment phase. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a variation of the multiple baseline design?
quizquestion.explanation: The multiple probe design is considered a variation of the multiple baseline design. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design is uses intermittent measures to analyze the relation between the independent variable and the learning of a task sequence?
quizquestion.explanation: The multiple probe design is used to analyze the learning of subsequent skills in a chain. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design uses an initial baseline and intervention, then subsequent baselines are added to the design?
quizquestion.explanation: The delayed multiple baseline design

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the multiple probe design.

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the delayed multiple baseline design.

quizquestion.question: What is another term for intermittent measures to analyze the current levels of each phase?
quizquestion.explanation: Probe is another term for intermittent measures used to analyze the current levels of each phase. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The multiple probe design would be appropriate to use for which behavior goal?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Learning the steps to brush ones teeth
wrongAnswer: Establish which treatment is most effective.
quizquestion.explanation: learning the steps to brush ones teeth would be an appropriate behavior to address using a multiple probe design. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In a multiple probe design, while the first behavior is in baseline phase, the second behavior should be in which phase?
quizquestion.explanation: Probes should be conducted while the first behavior is in baseline phase. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In a multiple probe design, while the second behavior is in treatment/instruction phase, what should occur in the first phase?
quizquestion.explanation: During the second behavior is in treatment, the first behavior is probed to ensure it is maintained at an appropriate level. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following behaviors would be appropriate to target using a multiple probe design?
wrongAnswer: Learning the steps to using the bathroom
Learning how to brush one’s teeth
Learning how to wash one’s clothes
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are appropriate behaviors to target during a multiple probe design. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following behaviors would be appropriate to target using a multiple probe design?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Leaning the steps to using the bathroom
quizquestion.explanation: Learning the steps to using the bathroom would be appropriate to target using a multiple probe design. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design is uses intermittent measures to analyze the relation between the independent variable and the learning of a task sequence?
quizquestion.explanation: The multiple probe design is used to analyze the learning of subsequent skills in a chain. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design uses an initial baseline and intervention, and then subsequent baselines are added to the design?
quizquestion.explanation: The delayed multiple baseline design

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the multiple probe design.

quizquestion.question: Which experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the delayed multiple baseline design.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is the multiple baseline design.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: Changing criterion design is depicted.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an alternating treatments design.

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an A-B-A-B design.

quizquestion.question: Which treatment design excels at comparing multiple treatments to determine which is most effective?
quizquestion.explanation: Alternating treatments design excels at comparing multiple treatments to determine which is most effective. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What type of experimental design is depicted in this graph?
quizquestion.explanation: A-B-A design. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Conduct a component analysis to determine the effective components of an intervention package

quizquestion.question: This is defined as systematically comparing two or more independent variables that comprise a treatment package.
quizquestion.explanation: A component analysis is used to systematically compare two or more independent variables that comprise a treatment package. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: A component analysis compares how many different independent variables?
quizquestion.explanation: a component analysis is used to identify which component of the intervention is affecting the desired change. This is done by systematically comparing 2 or more different components of the intervention package. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: Jerry created a treatment package to address inappropriate sexual behavior. These components included the following components: DRA, Punishment, and response blocking. What should Jerry do to determine which parts of his treatment package are effective?
quizquestion.explanation: a component analysis is used to identify which component of the intervention is affecting the desired change. This is done by systematically comparing 2 or more different components of the intervention package. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: When making conclusions from a component analysis, it is important to consider the possibility that the effects of individual components of the treatment package are independent of each other. This effect is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: This is known as additive effects. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: When making conclusions from a component analysis, it is important to consider the possibility that the effects of one component might depend on the presence of another. This effect is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: This is known as multiplicative effects. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: When making conclusions from a component analysis, it is important to consider the possibility that the effects of one condition may carry over and influence behavior in subsequent conditions. This effect is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: Sequence effects occur when one condition may carry over and influence behavior in subsequent conditions. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: Jerry is conducting a component analysis on his treatment package consisting of DRA, punishment, and response blocking. He is currently using all three components in his treatment, and systematically removes treatments to determine which components are not necessary for improved behavior. Which method is Jerry using?
quizquestion.explanation: Jerry is using the dropout analysis method by systematically removing components to determine which is not necessary to use. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: Jerry is conducting a component analysis on his treatment package consisting of DRA, punishment, and response blocking. He hasn’t implemented this treatment yet, and begins by systematically testing one intervention at a time, and combining the treatments to determine their effect. Which method is Jerry using?
quizquestion.explanation: Jerry is using the add-in analysis by systematically adding components of the treatment to determine their effects. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: Jerry is implementing a token economy, and wants to know how much reinforcement he needs to provide to see the desired improved behavior. What analysis should Jerry conduct?
quizquestion.explanation: Jerry should conduct a parametric analysis. (Sy, Borrero, Zarcone, 2009)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as experimentally discovering the differential effects of a range of values of an independent variable.
quizquestion.explanation: A parametric analysis is defined as experimentally discovering the differential effects of a range of values of an independent variable. (Sy, Borrero, Zarcone, 2009)

phase.name: Conduct a parametric analysis to determine the effective values of an independent variable

quizquestion.question: Amy  is implementing a token economy, and wants to know how much reinforcement he needs to provide to see the desired improved behavior. What analysis should Amy conduct?
quizquestion.explanation: Jerry should conduct a parametric analysis. (Sy, Borrero, Zarcone, 2009)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as experimentally discovering the differential effects of a range of values of an independent variable.
quizquestion.explanation: A parametric analysis is defined as experimentally discovering the differential effects of a range of values of an independent variable. (Sy, Borrero, Zarcone, 2009)

quizquestion.question: This is defined as systematically comparing two or more independent variables that comprise a treatment package.
quizquestion.explanation: A component analysis is used to systematically compare two or more independent variables that comprise a treatment package. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: Amy created a treatment package to address inappropriate sexual behavior. These components included the following components: DRA, Punishment, and response blocking. What should Amy do to determine which parts of his treatment package are effective?
quizquestion.explanation: a component analysis is used to identify which component of the intervention is affecting the desired change. This is done by systematically comparing 2 or more different components of the intervention package. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: How many independent variables are under investigation when conducting a parametric analysis?
quizquestion.explanation: Parametric analyses investigate only one independent variable.

quizquestion.question: A component analysis compares how many different independent variables?
quizquestion.explanation: a component analysis is used to identify which component of the intervention is affecting the desired change. This is done by systematically comparing 2 or more different components of the intervention package. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: You’re client has made amazing progress! You want to determine if it was the reward component, the extinction procedure, or the response cost. What should you do?
quizquestion.explanation: A component analysis is used to systematically compare two or more independent variables that comprise a treatment package. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: You are implementing praise as a reinforcer, and want to know how frequently (or on what schedule) it would be most effective. What should you do?
quizquestion.explanation: A parametric analysis is defined as experimentally discovering the differential effects of a range of values of an independent variable. (Sy, Borrero, Zarcone, 2009)

quizquestion.question: You are determining if the progress your client has made is due to the level program, the praise delivered, or the nickels delivered as reinforcement. What should you do?
quizquestion.explanation: A component analysis is used to systematically compare two or more independent variables that comprise a treatment package. (Ward-Horner & Sturmey, 2010)

quizquestion.question: You want to determine how many tokens to remove during a response cost program for increased effectiveness. What should you do?
quizquestion.explanation: A parametric analysis is defined as experimentally discovering the differential effects of a range of values of an independent variable. (Sy, Borrero, Zarcone, 2009)

phase.name: State and plan for the possible unwanted effects of reinforcement

quizquestion.question: This principle of behavior occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the presentation of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Positive reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the presentation of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This principle of behavior occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the removal of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Negative reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the removal of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary’s mother reprimands Mary when she swears. Mary is more likely to swear later on, following the reprimand. This reprimand is functioning as a:
quizquestion.explanation: Although a reprimand is usually aversive, in this example, it is functioning as a positive reinforcer for Mary. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: An appetitive stimulus is:
quizquestion.explanation: An appetitive stimulus only SOMETIMES functions as a reinforcer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Reinforcement procedures fail to produce substantial results when:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Initial criterion for reinforcement is not easily achieved
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement procedures are most effective when high quality and varied reinforcers are used, contrived reinforcers are shifted to naturally occurring reinforcers, and the initial criterion for reinforcement is easily achieved. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Reinforcement procedures fail to produce substantial results when:
wrongAnswer: Initial criterion for reinforcement is easily achieved.
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement procedures are most effective when high quality and varied reinforcers are used, contrived reinforcers are shifted to naturally occurring reinforcers, and the initial criterion for reinforcement is easily achieved. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Reinforcement procedures fail to produce substantial results when:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The same reinforcer is repeatedly used
wrongAnswer: Initial criterion for reinforcement is easily achieved
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement procedures are most effective when high quality and varied reinforcers are used, contrived reinforcers are shifted to naturally occurring reinforcers, and the initial criterion for reinforcement is easily achieved. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Reinforcement procedures fail to produce substantial results when:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Contrived reinforcers are not shifted to naturally occurring reinforcers
wrongAnswer: Initial criterion for reinforcement is easily achieved
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement procedures are most effective when high quality and varied reinforcers are used, contrived reinforcers are shifted to naturally occurring reinforcers, and the initial criterion for reinforcement is easily achieved. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What happens when the initial criterion for reinforcement is not easily achieved?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The individual does not contact the contingency
wrongAnswer: It sets the standard high, to promote quicker learning
The learner will initially increase the frequency of the behavior rapidly, then progress will slow
The learner will initially increase the frequency of the behavior slowly, then progress will accelerate
quizquestion.explanation: The individual will not contact the contingency if the initial criterion is set too high. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When starting an intervention using reinforcement:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Each occurrence of the behavior should be reinforced
wrongAnswer: The behavior should be reinforced intermittently
Use the same reinforcer during each session
quizquestion.explanation: When starting an intervention using reinforcement, every response should be reinforced. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: State and plan for the possible unwanted effects of punishment

quizquestion.question: This occurs when there is a stimulus change following a behavior, and then there is a decrease if the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment occurs when stimulus change immediately follows a response, and decreases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This is a stimulus change, which produces a decrease in behavior when it immediately follows a response.
quizquestion.explanation: A punisher is the stimulus change in a punishment procedure. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The discontinuing of reinforcement is:
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction is the discontinuing of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Negative side effects of punishment include:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: An increase in other undesirable behaviors
wrongAnswer: Behavior change doesn’t occur with punishment alone
You may lose BCBA certification for ethical violations
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment may result in an increase in other undesirable behaviors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Negative side effects of punishment include:
wrongAnswer: Behavior change doesn’t occur with punishment alone
You may lose BCBA certification for ethical violations
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment may result in appropriate behaviors decreasing. If you reprimand a child for an incorrect answer, they may refuse to attempt to answer the next time. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Negative side effects of punishment include:
wrongAnswer: Behavior change doesn’t occur with punishment alone
You may lose BCBA certification for ethical violations
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment may result in emotional outbursts. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Negative effects of punishment include:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Punishing is reinforcing for the instructor
wrongAnswer: Behavior change doesn’t occur with punishment alone
You may lose BCBA certification for ethical violations
quizquestion.explanation: Punishing is reinforcing for the instructor. This may lead the instructor to implement punishment procedures in excess outside of the intervention. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Negative effects of punishment include:
wrongAnswer: Punishing is reinforcing for the instructor
quizquestion.explanation: All of the answers above are possible concerns with punishment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: To use punishment appropriately, you should:
wrongAnswer: Use the least restrictive intervention that can be effective
Use a punisher with sufficient magnitude
quizquestion.explanation: All of the answers above are correct. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: To use punishment appropriately, you should:
wrongAnswer: Use a mild punisher, then increase the magnitude if needed
Use only punishment to ensure the intervention is run correctly
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement interventions should be used on conjunction with punishment procedures. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: State and plan for the possible unwanted effects of extinction

quizquestion.question: The discontinuing of reinforcement is:
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction is the discontinuing of reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During extinction, a behavior may decrease to the point that the behavior no longer occurs, then, seemingly out of nowhere, the behavior occurs. This is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: This is known as spontaneous recovery. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During extinction, there is typically an immediate increase in the frequency of the response. This is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: Extinct bursts occur when there is an immediate increase in the frequency of the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During extinction:
wrongAnswer: The behavior should decrease slowly but steadily
quizquestion.explanation: During extinction, behavior tends to increase initially (extinction burst). (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When using extinction, the instructor should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Withhold reinforcement for all occurrences of the behavior
wrongAnswer: Withhold reinforcement for most occurrences of the behavior
Withhold reinforcement until an extinction burst occurs
Withhold reinforcement until spontaneous recovery occurs
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement must be withheld for ALL occurrences of the behavior, or there is potential for reinforcing an extinction burst. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Delivering reinforcement during an extinction burst would likely:
wrongAnswer: Increase the frequency of the behavior even more
Be worse than reinforcing initial occurrences of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Delivering reinforcement during an extinction burst would do all of the above. Although it calms the individual down, it will also reinforce an increased frequency and intensity of the behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Unwanted effects of extinction include:
quizquestion.explanation: all of the answers above are correct. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Unwanted effects of extinction include:
wrongAnswer: Can be combined with other interventions
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction can lead to increased aggression from the learner. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When dealing with dangerous behaviors such as serious self-harm behavior:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Extinction should not be used as a single intervention
wrongAnswer: Extinction must occur for every occurrence of the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction should not be used as a single intervention for very dangerous behaviors. Extinction may be combined with punishment, reinforcement, and/or antecedent interventions for a safer intervention package. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Informing the individual about the extinction procedure at the beginning of the session:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: May help diminish behavior more rapidly
quizquestion.explanation: Informing the individual about the extinction procedure at the beginning of the session may help diminish behavior more rapidly. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This principle of behavior occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the presentation of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Positive reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the presentation of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This principle of behavior occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the removal of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Negative reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the removal of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This principle of behavior occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the removal of a stimulus that decreases the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment is discussed in a different quiz, but occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the removal of a stimulus that decreases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary’s mother reprimands Mary when she swears. Mary is more likely to swear later on, following the reprimand. This reprimand is functioning as a:
quizquestion.explanation: Although a reprimand is usually aversive, in this example, it is functioning as a positive reinforcer for Mary. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary’s mother reprimands Mary when she swears. Mary is less likely to swear later on, following the reprimand. This reprimand is functioning as a:
quizquestion.explanation: Punishment is discussed in a different quiz, but this is an example of a positive punisher. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of contingency most often requires an aversive antecedent from which the learner will escape or avoid.
quizquestion.explanation: Negative reinforcement typically requires an aversive stimulus from which the learner will escape or avoid. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jared cleans his room, and he gets $5. Jared is more likely to clean his room in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Positive reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the presentation of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jared’s mom reprimands at him for not cleaning his room. Jared cleans his room and his mom immediately stops yelling. Jared is more likely to clean his room in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Negative reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the removal of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Claire lives in a group home with staff supervision during the day. The staff give Claire a token (as part of a token economy) every time she brushes her teeth. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: We don’t know if brushing teeth increased in frequency following the token delivery. This is an attempt at positive reinforcement, but we don’t know the outcome. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The seat belt alarm is going off in Manuel’s car. He buckles his seatbelt and the noise turns of. Manuel is more likely to engage in this behavior in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Negative reinforcement occurs when a behavior is followed immediately by the removal of a stimulus that increases the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use appropriate parameters and schedules of reinforcement

quizquestion.question: This Compound  schedule of reinforcement occurs when 2 contingencies are operating simultaneously and independently for two or more behaviors. This schedule provides choice for the individual, and occurs frequently in the natural environment.
quizquestion.explanation: Concurrent schedules of reinforcement occur when 2 contingencies are operating simultaneously and independently for two or more behaviors. This schedule provides choice for the individual, and occurs frequently in the natural environment. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Compound schedule of reinforcement occurs when two or more schedules of reinforcement occur in an alternating, usually random sequence. A discriminative stimulus is correlated with each schedule.
quizquestion.explanation: Multiple schedules of reinforcement occur when two or more schedules of reinforcement occur in an alternating, usually random sequence. A discriminative stimulus is correlated with each schedule. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Compound schedule of reinforcement occurs when two or more schedules of reinforcement are occurring successively and in a specific order. There is a discriminative stimulus correlated with each schedule.
quizquestion.explanation: Chained schedules occur when two or more schedules of reinforcement are occurring successively and in a specific order. There is a discriminative stimulus correlated with each schedule. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Compound schedule of reinforcement is identical to a multiple schedule ,however there is no discriminative stimulus.
quizquestion.explanation: Mixed schedules are identical to a multiple schedule ,however there is no discriminative stimulus. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Compound schedule of reinforcement is identical to the chained schedule, but there are no discriminative stimuli with the elements in the chain.
quizquestion.explanation: Tandem schedules are identical to chained schedule, but there are no discriminative stimuli with the elements in the chain. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Compound schedule of reinforcement provides reinforcement whenever the requirement of EITHER a ratio schedule or an interval schedule is met.
quizquestion.explanation: Alternative schedules occur when reinforcement is provided whenever the requirement of EITHER a ratio schedule or an interval schedule is met. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Compound schedule of reinforcement provided reinforcement when the requirement of BOTH a ratio schedule and an interval schedule are met.
quizquestion.explanation: Conjunctive schedules of reinforcement occur when reinforcement is provided when the requirement of BOTH a ratio schedule and an interval schedule are met. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Intermittent  schedule of reinforcement provides reinforcement whenever the learner engages in an exact number of responses.
quizquestion.explanation: A fixed ratio schedule provides reinforcement whenever the learner engages in an exact number of responses. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Intermittent schedule of reinforcement provides reinforcement whenever the learner engages in a number of responses that vary from trial to trial, but average to the specific number of responses.
quizquestion.explanation: Variable ratio schedule provides reinforcement whenever the learner engages in a number of responses that vary from trial to trial, but average to the specific number of responses. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This Intermittent Schedule of reinforcement provides reinforcement after the first response following a specific duration of time.
quizquestion.explanation: Fixed interval schedule provides reinforcement after the first response following a specific duration of time. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. After saying “Where is the red card?” he places his hand on hers, moving her hand until she selects the correct card. This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Full physical prompts include hand over hand manipulation to aid the learner to the correct answer.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. After saying “Where is the red card?” he places his hand on hers moving her hand until she is moving her hand in the correct direction, then he lets go. This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Partial physical prompts include moving the learner’s body in the direction of the correct response.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. After saying “Where is the red card?” Alex touches the correct response, demonstrating the correct response. This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Modeling includes the instructor demonstrating the correct response for the learner.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. After saying “Where is the red card?” Alex points in the direction of the correct card. This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Gestural prompts include pointing or gesturing towards the next step of completing the task.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. After saying “Where is the red card?” The red card is slightly larger than the pink card. This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Visual prompts involve creating brighter colored or larger stimuli to indicate the correct response.

quizquestion.question: Alex is a BCBA using errorless learning to teach a child to discriminate between red and pink. Alex says “Where is the red card? Lift your hand up and touch the card closer to you.” This is an example of which kind of prompt?
quizquestion.explanation: Verbal prompts include telling the learner the steps necessary to complete the task.

quizquestion.question: Which prompt method would be used first when using most to least prompting?
quizquestion.explanation: most to least prompting involves using the most intrusive prompt first and gradually fades to less intrusive prompts.

quizquestion.question: Which prompt method would most likely be used first when using least to most prompting
quizquestion.explanation: Visual prompts are the least intrusive answer above. Least to most prompting is completed by giving the learner an opportunity to respond correctly prior to moving on to more intrusive prompting.

quizquestion.question: Sam is asked to brush his teeth. The instructor immediately puts his hand on Sam’s and guides him through the first steps. Which prompting method is used?
quizquestion.explanation: most to least prompting involves using the most intrusive prompt first and gradually fades to less intrusive prompts.

quizquestion.question: Sam is asked to brush his teeth. Sam doesn’t respond after 3 seconds so the instructor says “grab the toothpaste”. Which prompting method is likely being used?
quizquestion.explanation: Least to most prompting is completed by giving the learner an opportunity to respond correctly prior to moving on to more intrusive prompting.

quizquestion.question: Modeling is a great teaching strategy, but requires the learner to have which skill prior to being effective?
quizquestion.explanation: Prior to modeling being effective, the learner must possess imitative skills. Attending is a prerequisite to imitating, so both skills are necessary.

quizquestion.question: In modeling, how can you tell if there is a controlling relation between the learner and the model?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: If the learner engages in novel behaviors that have not been reinforced in the known history, following the model’s behavior.
wrongAnswer: If the Model engages in novel behaviors that have not been reinforced in the known history, following the learner’s behavior.
If the learner engages in novel behaviors, different from those behaviors being modeled.
If the Model engages in novel behaviors, different from those behaviors being modeled.
quizquestion.explanation: There is a controlling relation when the learner engages in novel behaviors that have not been reinforced in the known history, following the model’s behavior.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of a controlling relation with modeling?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Amy throws a ball to Paul, who throws the ball back to Amy. They play catch often.
wrongAnswer: Amy throws a ball to Paul, who throws the ball back to Amy. Paul had never thrown a ball before.
quizquestion.explanation: There is a controlling relation when the learner engages in novel behaviors that have not been reinforced in the known history, following the model’s behavior.

quizquestion.question: Prior to conducting imitation training, the learner should already possess which skill?
quizquestion.explanation: Prior to conducting imitation training, the learner should already be able to attend to the instructor. If not, attending should be trained first.

quizquestion.question: While starting imitation training, the instructor should reinforce:
wrongAnswer: Any response that is correct or incorrect
quizquestion.explanation: While starting imitation training, the instructor should reinforce both prompted and imitative responses.

quizquestion.question: Jane is just starting to conduct imitation training with Fred. Jane says “do this” as she touches her head. Fred doesn’t respond. What should Jane do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Deliver a prompt so Fred responds correctly, then deliver a reinforcer
wrongAnswer: Move on to a different question
Keep asking until he responds correctly
quizquestion.explanation: When an individual does not respond correctly, the instructor should prompt the individual so they respond correctly, then deliver a reinforcer.

quizquestion.question: Jane is just starting to conduct imitation training with Fred. Jane says “do this” as she touches her head. Fred touches his belly.  What should Jane do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Deliver a prompt so Fred responds correctly, then deliver a reinforcer
wrongAnswer: Move on to a different question
Keep asking until he responds correctly
quizquestion.explanation: When an individual does not respond correctly, the instructor should prompt the individual so they respond correctly, then deliver a reinforcer.

quizquestion.question: Jane is just starting to conduct imitation training with Fred. Jane says “do this” as she touches her head. Fred touches his head.  What should Jane do?
wrongAnswer: Deliver a prompt so Fred responds correctly, then deliver a reinforcer
Move on to a different question
Keep asking until he responds correctly
quizquestion.explanation: When an individual responds correctly, they should be reinforced.

quizquestion.question: Mandy is conducting imitation training. Praise is not reinforcing for the learner at this time, but small edibles are. Mandy should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Use small edibles as reinforcement ALWAYS paired with praise
wrongAnswer: Use small edibles as reinforcement SOMETIMES paired with praise
Use praise anyways, until it’s reinforcing
quizquestion.explanation: Tangible items may be used as reinforcement, however they should always be paired with praise, so praise can be established as a reinforcer.

quizquestion.question: Training sessions for imitation training should be:
quizquestion.explanation: Training sessions for imitation training should be active and brief.

quizquestion.question: Shaping is defined as
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Systematically and differentially reinforcing successive approximations to a terminal behavior
wrongAnswer: Reinforcement is provided for correct responses and withheld for incorrect responses
A stimulus whose presentation functions as reinforcement
quizquestion.explanation: Shaping is defined as systematically and differentially reinforcing successive approximations to a terminal behavior

quizquestion.question: Differential reinforcement is defined as
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Reinforcement is provided for correct responses and withheld for incorrect responses
wrongAnswer: A stimulus whose presentation functions as reinforcement
Systematically and differentially reinforcing successive approximations to a terminal behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Differential reinforcement is defined as reinforcement is provided for correct responses and withheld for incorrect responses

quizquestion.question: Behavior can be shaped in terms of
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior can be shaped in terms of frequency, topography, duration, latency, or intensity.

quizquestion.question: Danny plays the cello. His mother wants him to increase the amount of time he practices the cello each day. He is currently practicing 20 minutes per day, on average. Using differential reinforcement how might the mother shape this behavior to increase his average time to 30 minutes per day?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Reinforce only practices that go longer than 20 minutes, gradually changing the criteria as the average lengthens.
wrongAnswer: Reinforce only practices that go 30 minutes or longer.
Reinforce practices that go longer than 15 minutes, gradually changing the criteria as the average lengthens.
Timing is optional. Reinforce any practice that feels longer than typical practices.
quizquestion.explanation: The mother should reinforce only practices that go longer than 20 minutes, gradually changing the criteria as the average lengthens.

quizquestion.question: Danny plays the cello. His mother wants him to increase the amount of time he practices the cello each day. Which dimension of behavior should be shaped?
quizquestion.explanation: Duration is being shaped.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is not a limitation of shaping?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Shaping can change a variety of dimensions of behavior including duration, latency, and frequency.
wrongAnswer: Progress is not always linear across criteria
quizquestion.explanation: Some limitations of shaping include that it is often time consuming, requires constant supervision, and progress is not always linear across criteria.

quizquestion.question: John used to require hand over hand prompting to brush his teeth, but now only requires visual prompts. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of prompt fading.

quizquestion.question: John used to yell at loud volumes to get his mother’s attention. Using differential reinforcement, John now speaks in a soft voice as he’s requesting attention. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of shaping

quizquestion.question: John yells at loud volumes to get his mother’s attention. His mother reinforces close approximations to low volumes and ignores loud volumes. The process of reinforcing appropriate responses and not reinforcing inappropriate responses is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of differential reinforcement.

quizquestion.question: John wants to start eating healthier foods. He currently eats only foods with high amounts of sugar. He wants to have a more balanced diet with high amounts of nutrients. Changing this behavior would be shaping across which dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Cooking and eating different foods changes the topography of the behavior.

quizquestion.question: What is a behavior chain?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement
wrongAnswer: Various methods used for linking specific sequences together
Behaviors that may look different, but all result in the same reinforcement
Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units.
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior chains are a specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is Chaining?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Various methods used for linking specific sequences together
wrongAnswer: Behaviors that may look different, but all result in the same reinforcement
Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units.
A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement
quizquestion.explanation: Chaining includes various methods used for linking specific sequences together. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a task analysis?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units.
wrongAnswer: A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement
Various methods used for linking specific sequences together
Behaviors that may look different, but all result in the same reinforcement
quizquestion.explanation: Task analyses involve breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Prior to using chaining, a ______must be completed.
quizquestion.explanation: A task analysis is completed prior to chaining. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary is learning to tie her shoes. The BCBA conducted a task analysis and is focusing on 8 smaller steps from “1. Placing on string in each hand” to “8. Pull the loops away from each other”. Mary is reinforced for correctly completing the first step. She then completes the first step and the second step and is reinforced after correctly completing both steps. What type of chaining is being used?
quizquestion.explanation: Forward chaining is completed by  reinforcing accurate responding of the first step. Then, progressing with the chaining, the learner must complete the first steps previously learned AND the new step to receive reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary is learning to tie her shoes. The BCBA conducted a task analysis and is focusing on 8 smaller steps from “1. Placing on string in each hand” to “8. Pull the loops away from each other”. The BCBA teaches each step during every session, providing prompts for correct responding, and reinforcement after correct responding.
quizquestion.explanation: Total task chaining is completed by providing training for every step during every session. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary is learning to tie her shoes. The BCBA conducted a task analysis and is focusing on 8 smaller steps from “1. Placing on string in each hand” to “8. Pull the loops away from each other”. The BCBA completes the first 7 steps for Mary, and then provides prompting so Mary completes the last step correctly. The BCBA then provides reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: Backward chaining is conducted by completing each step for the learner until the last step. Once the learner can correctly complete the last step, the instructor completes all steps except the last two steps. This process continues, providing reinforcement for correct responses, until all steps are mastered. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Lucas is learning to take a shower. 10 steps are broken down from turning the water on to an appropriate temperature, to drying the body with a towel. The BCBA begins working with Lucas by starting with turning the water on. During the first session she goes through each step of showering, providing prompts and reinforcement along the way. Which method of chaining is being used?
quizquestion.explanation: Total task chaining is completed by providing training for every step during every session. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Lucas is learning to take a shower. 10 steps are broken down from turning the water on to an appropriate temperature, to drying the body with a towel. The BCBA begins working with Lucas by starting with turning the water on. After correctly completing the first step independently (after several sessions), Lucas is required to complete the first AND the second step before receiving reinforcement Which method of chaining is being used?
quizquestion.explanation: Forward chaining is completed by  reinforcing accurate responding of the first step. Then, progressing with the chaining, the learner must complete the first steps previously learned AND the new step to receive reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Lucas is learning to take a shower. 10 steps are broken down from turning the water on to an appropriate temperature, to drying the body with a towel. The BCBA begins working with Lucas by completing the first 9 steps of showering for Lucas. Then teaches Lucas how to correctly dry off with the towel and provides reinforcement for correct responding. Which method of chaining is being used?
quizquestion.explanation: Backward chaining is conducted by completing each step for the learner until the last step. Once the learner can correctly complete the last step, the instructor completes all steps except the last two steps. This process continues, providing reinforcement for correct responses, until all steps are mastered. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a task analysis?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units.
wrongAnswer: A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement
Various methods used for linking specific sequences together
Behaviors that may look different, but all result in the same reinforcement
quizquestion.explanation: Task analyses involve breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a behavior chain?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement
wrongAnswer: Various methods used for linking specific sequences together
Behaviors that may look different, but all result in the same reinforcement
Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units.
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior chains are a specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following tasks would be most important to break up into smaller steps using a task analysis if it were to be taught to novice learner?
quizquestion.explanation: task analyses are used to break up behaviors composed of multiple steps. Single step tasks would not usually need to be broken up further. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following tasks would be most important to break up into smaller steps using a task analysis if it were to be taught to novice learner?
quizquestion.explanation: task analyses are used to break up behaviors composed of multiple steps. Single step tasks would not usually need to be broken up further. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which is a research based method of developing a task analysis?
wrongAnswer: Consulting with an expert on the skill
quizquestion.explanation: Task analyses can be developed by observing a competent performer, consulting with an expert on the skill, or by performing the behaviors oneself. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: If you were to conduct a task analysis on putting on pants, which might be the first step outlined in the task analysis?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Select one pair of pants from the bottom drawer the dresser
wrongAnswer: Deliver one reinforcer as soon as the individual correctly puts their pants on
Select one pair of pants from the dresser and step in to the pants
Prompt the individual to put pants on.
quizquestion.explanation: The first step of a task analysis should be the first basic task necessary for the individual to complete. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: “Breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units” is the definition of:
quizquestion.explanation: Task analyses involve breaking up a complex skill into smaller, teachable units. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: “A specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement” is the definition of:
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior chains are a specific sequence of discrete responses ending with reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When teaching a new skill to an individual, what can be done only after completing a task analysis?
quizquestion.explanation: Chaining can be completed only after a task analysis. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In a behavior chain, conditioned reinforcement for the first step, should also be the ______ for the next step.
quizquestion.explanation: In a behavior chain, condition reinforcement for the first step, should also be the SD for the next step. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the learner is given repeated contrived opportunities to emit the response.
quizquestion.explanation: Discrete-trials occur when the learner is given repeated contrived opportunities to emit the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs in the natural setting, and the instructor looks out for natural learning opportunities.
quizquestion.explanation: Free-operant procedures occur in the natural setting, and the instructor looks out for natural learning opportunities. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which measure would not be appropriate to use during discrete-trials?
wrongAnswer: All of these would be appropriate measures
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is not an appropriate measure for most discrete trials, because the responses occur in a contrived situation. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Martha is learning how to read. An RBT is working with her using flashcards. Martha is most likely participating in:
quizquestion.explanation: Martha is most likely participating in discrete trials. Using flashcards is creating contrived contingencies for learning. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Martha is trying to lose weight. She is focusing on increasing exercise and decreasing caloric intake. She is tracking her calories, and her friend is providing reinforcement each day in the form of attention for following her plan. Martha is most likely participating in:
quizquestion.explanation: Free-operant procedures occur in the natural setting, and the instructor looks out for natural learning opportunities. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Discrete trials should be conducted by:
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above can effectively implement discrete trials, even parents! (Lafasakis & Sturmey, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Luke is helping his student learn her colors. Luke presents a red card and a yellow card and says “touch the red card”. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Discrete-trials occur when the learner is given repeated contrived opportunities to emit the response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Martha earns a high five every time she independently makes her bed in the morning. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Free-operant procedures occur in the natural setting, and the instructor looks out for natural learning opportunities. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: The instructor may provide reinforcement for appropriate/correct responses during this procedure:
quizquestion.explanation: delivering reinforcement for appropriate responses occurs in essentially every behavioral intervention whether it is a free operant procedure or a discrete trial. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Differential reinforcement may be used in:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Both free operant procedures AND discrete trials
wrongAnswer: Neither discrete trials nor free operant procedures.
quizquestion.explanation: Differential reinforcement can be used in both free operant procedures as well as discrete trials. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Use the verbal operants as a basis for language assessment

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a nonverbal SD and results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The Tact is under the functional control of a nonverbal SD and results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and the verbal operant have point to point correspondence and formal similarity. It results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The echoic is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and the verbal operant have point to point correspondence and formal similarity. It results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The intraverbal is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant occurs when a speaker’s own verbal behavior functions as an SD or an MO for additional speaker verbal behavior. The speaker is the listener and observer.
quizquestion.explanation: The autoclitic occurs when a speaker’s own verbal behavior functions as an SD or an MO for additional speaker verbal behavior. The speaker is the listener and observer. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant has point to point correspondence, but not formal similarity between the stimulus and response. It occurs when upon seeing a written word, the speaker “reads” the word.
quizquestion.explanation: The textual operant has point to point correspondence, but not formal similarity between the stimulus and response. It occurs when upon seeing a written word, the speaker “reads” the word. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant has point to point correspondence, but not formal similarity between the stimulus and response. It occurs when the speaker hears a spoken word and then produces a written word.
quizquestion.explanation: The transcription operant has point to point correspondence, but not formal similarity between the stimulus and response. It occurs when the speaker hears a spoken word and then produces a written word. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: A young boy is tired and says “bed”. His mother puts him down for a nap. “Bed” in this example is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: A young boy sees a bed and says “bed”. His mother responds by saying “That is a bed, good job!” “Bed” in this example is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The Tact is under the functional control of a nonverbal SD and results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: A mother asks her son “where do you go to sleep?” The boy responds with “bed”. “Bed” in this example is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The intraverbal is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and the verbal operant have point to point correspondence and formal similarity. It results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The echoic is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and the verbal operant have point to point correspondence and formal similarity. It results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The intraverbal is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: A mother asks her son “where do you go to sleep?” The boy responds with “bed”. “Bed” in this example is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The intraverbal is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: A mother says “bed”, her son replies “bed”.  “bed” in this example is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The echoic is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and the verbal operant have point to point correspondence and formal similarity. It results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: Why is echoic training important?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The ability to repeat words when asked to do so plays a major role in learning other verbal operants
wrongAnswer: So the individual can request items when and where the individual pleases
Tantrums will be avoided if a child can echo behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic training because the ability to repeat words when asked to do so plays a major role in learning other verbal operants. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Andrew just started conducting echoic training with a young child. Andrew says “Ball”, and the child repeats back “Bubu”. This is the closest the child has come to saying ball. Andrew should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Provide praise or other generalized conditioned reinforcer
wrongAnswer: Repeat the word “Ball” so the child will try again
Don’t respond until the child says “ball” more clearly
Deliver feedback. Say something like “Bubu” was pretty close, but I need you to say it more clearly like “Baaalllll”
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic training uses shaping. Shaping takes place by reinforcing successive aproximations of the behavior. “bubu” is pretty close. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Andrew just started conducting echoic training with a young child. Andrew says “Ball”, and the child repeats back “Bubu”. The child is able to say “ball”, but did not do so during this opportunity. Andrew should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Repeat the word “Ball” so the child will try again
wrongAnswer: Provide praise or other generalized conditioned reinforcer
Don’t respond until the child says “ball” more clearly
Deliver feedback. Say something like “Bubu” was pretty close, but I need you to say it more clearly like “Baaalllll”
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic training uses shaping. Shaping takes place by reinforcing successive aproximations of the behavior. If the child has recently said “ball”, “bubu” should not be accepted as a correct response. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Shaping is defined as
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Systematically and differentially reinforcing successive approximations to a terminal behavior
wrongAnswer: Reinforcement is provided for correct responses and withheld for incorrect responses
A stimulus whose presentation functions as reinforcement
quizquestion.explanation: Shaping is defined as systematically and differentially reinforcing successive approximations to a terminal behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Josh just began conducting echoic training with a child. The child rarely emits vocal responses of any sort. When josh says a word for the child to repeat, he typically just sits there non-responsive to the prompt. What can Josh do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Reinforce any vocalization that occurs, even if it doesn’t resemble the word at this time.
wrongAnswer: Wait until the child repeats the word to provide reinforcement
Deliver feedback to the child saying “you need to repeat what I’m saying”.
Continue to repeat the word until the child says the word.
quizquestion.explanation: If a child is not vocalizing very much, their opportunity for reinforcement is low. Reinforcing all occurrences of vocalization, starting out, is an appropriate direction to go. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Susan is working with a child helping him engage in echoic responses. Susan says “Train” and the child says “train”. The child has already said “train” in the past. Susan should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Provide praise or other generalized conditioned reinforcer
wrongAnswer: Repeat the word “train” so the child will try again
Don’t respond until the child says “train” more clearly
Do not provide praise and move on to the next word.
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic training uses shaping. Shaping takes place by reinforcing successive aproximations of the behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a nonverbal SD and results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The Tact is under the functional control of a nonverbal SD and results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: Why is learning the mand so important for early development?
wrongAnswer: To prevent tantrums and other inappropriate behavior
So the learner can get what he wants, when he wants it
To establish a child’s role as a speaker, rather than just a listener
quizquestion.explanation: All of the answers above are important reason to learn the mand in early development. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What must be present before conducting mand training?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The relevant MO must be strong and present
quizquestion.explanation: The relevant MO must be strong and present for mand training to be effective. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following would probably NOT be a good item to use as reinforcement for mand training?
quizquestion.explanation: It is important to select mands that have a powerful MO for the child. Chores, generally, would not be included. Every child is different so this will change based on the idiosyncrasies of the child. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During mand training, a child reaches for a pretzel.  The BCBA grabs the pretzel and says “pretzel”. The child repeats the word and says “pretzel”. What should the BCBA use as reinforcement?
wrongAnswer: It depends on the result  of the preference assessment
quizquestion.explanation: During mand training, the reinforcement should always be the specific item being asked for. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Joey loves candy. Right after lunch, you have a bowl of Joey’s favorite candy and are ready to start mand training. Joey is watching Batman on TV (his favorite show) and isn’t showing interest in the candy. You should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Use the TV show as the focus of mand training.
wrongAnswer: Sit there and wait until he is interested in candy.
Turn off the TV so the child can focus on the candy
quizquestion.explanation: Mand training can only be effective if there is a powerful MO in place. If the child isn’t hungry, changing the mand training to focus on another interest would be best. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During mand training, which responses are appropriate:
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above can be used as response forms for mands, however vocal words are most common. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During mand training, a child reaches for the TV remote to watch his show.  The BCBA grabs the remote and says “batman”. The child repeats the word and says “batman”. What should the BCBA use as reinforcement?
wrongAnswer: Depends on the result of the preference assessment
quizquestion.explanation: During mand training, the reinforcement should always be the specific item being asked for. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are teaching the word “pretzels” during mand training. The child is no longer showing interest in pretzels but is reaching for your water bottle. You should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Have him say “water”, and give him water
wrongAnswer: Give him some water, then continue on with pretzels after he isn’t thirsty
Remove the water bottle, as it’s a distraction
Continue to use pretzels as the focus of the training
quizquestion.explanation: Mand training can only be effective if there is a powerful MO in place. If the child isn’t hungry, changing the mand training to focus on another interest would be best. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a nonverbal SD and results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The Tact is under the functional control of a nonverbal SD and results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The intraverbal is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: Philip knows how to mand, but has no echoic or tact skills. Which type of tact training might benefit Philip?
quizquestion.explanation: Mand to tact training takes place when the learner is able to mand and not able to tact. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Philip uses echoic operants, but does not have a history with tacts or mands. To train Philip on mands, which type of training would be best?
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic to tact training would be useful if the individual has echoic abilities. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: When the child is hungry, Nathan presents a treat. The child says “treat”. Nathan delivers the treat AND praise. Nathan then fades the MO of hunger and the treat as reinforcement in following sessions. What tact training procedure is Nathan implementing?
quizquestion.explanation: Mand to tact training takes place when the learner is able to mand and not able to tact. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Nathan presents a toy tractor and says “What is this? Tractor”. The child says “Tractor”. Nathan delivers praise. Nathan then is able to present the tractor and says “What is this?” The child responds with “Tractor”. Nathan delivers praise once again. Next, Nathan simply presents the tractor, and the child says “Tractor”. This is an example of which kind of tact training?
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic to tact training would be useful if the individual has echoic abilities. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: A young boy sees a bed and says “bed”. His mother responds by saying “That is a bed, good job!” “Bed” in this example is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The Tact is under the functional control of a nonverbal SD and results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: A young boy is tired and says “bed”. His mother puts him down for a nap. “Bed” in this example is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: What should be the SD for a boy to tact “Airplane”?
wrongAnswer: The vocal word “airplane” spoken by another person
The vocal word “airplane” spoken by the speaker himself.
quizquestion.explanation: The SD for a tact should be the item itself. In this example it is the airplane. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: If a boy says “airplane” as a tact. What should reinforce this behavior?
wrongAnswer: The toy airplane he is asking for
Nothing. The boy should be intrinsically motivated to tact without the need for reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: Tacts result in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following verbal operants is typically most challenging to learn for individuals with developmental disabilities?
quizquestion.explanation: Intraverbal repertoires are typically the most challenging for individuals with developmental disabilities to learn. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement.
quizquestion.explanation: The intraverbal is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: This verbal operant occurs when a speaker’s own verbal behavior functions as an SD or an MO for additional speaker verbal behavior. The speaker is the listener and observer.
quizquestion.explanation: The autoclitic occurs when a speaker’s own verbal behavior functions as an SD or an MO for additional speaker verbal behavior. The speaker is the listener and observer. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: The BCBA says “what time do you go to sleep?” The child responds “8” This is an example of which verbal operant?
quizquestion.explanation: The intraverbal is under the functional control of a verbal SD. The SD and verbal operant do not have point-to-point correspondence. This operant results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: The mother says “it’s 8pm, it’s time to go to sleep!” The child goes into bed. The mother’s verbal behavior is an example of which verbal operant?
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is under control of motivating operations and results in specific reinforcement. (Skinner, 1957)

quizquestion.question: Prior to conducting intraverbal training, the child should have a substantial repertoire of which behaviors?
