quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are likely behavioral cusps

quizquestion.question: Which of the following behaviors is most likely a behavioral cusp?
wrongAnswer: Identifying “truck” from an array of images
quizquestion.explanation: Reading is likely a behavioral cusp

quizquestion.question: Which of the following behaviors is most likely a behavioral cusp?
quizquestion.explanation: Using public transportation system is likely a behavioral cusp.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following behaviors is most likely a behavioral cusp?
wrongAnswer: Identifying “truck” from an array of images
quizquestion.explanation: Driving a car is likely a behavioral cusp

quizquestion.question: Which of the following behaviors is most likely a behavioral cusp?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are likely behavioral cusps.

phase.name: Arrange instructional procedures to promote generative learning

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a learner emits untrained responses that are functionally equivalent to the trained target behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Response generalization occurs when a learner emits untrained responses that are functionally equivalent to the trained target behavior. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a learner emits the trained response in an untrained setting or situation.
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus generalization occurs when the learner emits the trained response in an untrained setting or situation. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: One way for promoting generalization and maintenance is to make the instructional setting similar to the generalized setting. How might you do that?
wrongAnswer: Randomly vary noncritical aspects of the instructional setting
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are methods for promoting generalization. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Ella is learning job skills in a classroom. Before going in to the workplace, the instructor makes the classroom feel as much like a workplace as possible including many features of the jobsite in the classroom. This is an example of:
wrongAnswer: Randomly varying noncritical aspects of the instructional setting
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of programming common stimuli. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This strategy promoting generalization requires instructors to randomly vary noncritical aspects of the instructional setting.
quizquestion.explanation: Teaching loosely requires instructors to randomly vary noncritical aspects of the instructional setting. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: While preparing to take the BCBA exam, you study thousands of practice questions to ensure you have studied enough possible variations of concepts to pass the exam. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of teaching sufficient examples. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Engaging in behaviors that are not taught, but they are learned through derived relations, refers to what?
quizquestion.explanation: Generative learning refers to engaging in behaviors that are not taught, but they are learned through derived relations. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: You are conducting discrimination training, and you frequently change the type of clothing you wear, change the decorations in the room, and change odors by using different scented candles. None of these stimuli are directly related to the discrimination training. What are you doing?
quizquestion.explanation: You are teaching loosely by mixing up stimuli not directly related to the training. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jen was taught to wash dishes using a sponge. When a sponge was not available she washed dishes with a dish rag, without being taught how to use a dish rag. This is evidence of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is response generalization. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Jen was taught to wash dishes using a sponge while at her house. She is at her friend’s house and helps wash dishes. This is evidence of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of stimulus generalization. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Base decision-making on data displayed in various formats

quizquestion.question: You are working with a client who engages in bullying. You begin to address the behavior using a behavioral intervention without collecting any baseline data. Which of the following is the best course of action moving forward, assuming the graph below is displaying your client’s bullying behavior?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Remove the intervention and collect baseline data
wrongAnswer: Praise the client for their improved behavior
quizquestion.explanation: The intervention does not appear to be working; however without baseline data we cannot be sure.

quizquestion.question: You are working with a client who engages in bullying. You begin to address the behavior using a behavioral intervention without collecting any baseline data. Which of the following is the best course of action moving forward, assuming the graph below is displaying your client’s bullying behavior?
wrongAnswer: Remove the intervention and collect baseline data
quizquestion.explanation: Although the improving data is variable, it appears to be decreasing. Continued implementation of the intervention is justified by the improvements the client has made.

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows for data to be displayed between two dimensions (e.g., frequency of behavior across time). Each data point is connect to the next with a line.
quizquestion.explanation: Line graphs allow for data to be displayed between two dimensions (e.g., frequency of behavior across time). Each data point is connect to the next with a line. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows you to display and compare discrete sets of data that are not related to one another by a common underlying dimension by which the horizontal axis can be scaled.
quizquestion.explanation: The bar graph allows you to display and compare discrete sets of data that are not related to one another by a common underlying dimension by which the horizontal axis can be scaled. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected.
quizquestion.explanation: The scatterplot shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph allows you to discover the temporal distribution of a target behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: The scatterplot shows the relative distribution of individual measures in a data set with respect to the variables depicted by the x and y axes. Data points are unconnected. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph displays the total number of responses emitted during a single session of observation.
quizquestion.explanation: The cumulative record displays the total number of responses emitted during a single session of observation. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This type of graph is used to display behaviors that are accelerating or decelerating in rate. The vertical axis displays frequency at increasing and non-proportional increments.
quizquestion.explanation: The standard celeration chart is used to display behaviors that are accelerating or decelerating in rate. The vertical axis displays frequency at increasing and non-proportional increments. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which axis is the x axis (or abscissa)?
quizquestion.explanation: The x axis is also known as the horizontal axis, or abscissa. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which axis is the y axis (or ordinate)?
quizquestion.explanation: The y axis is the vertical axis, or ordinate. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

phase.name: Provide for ongoing documentation of behavioral services

quizquestion.question: Why is it important to document behavior services you provide?
wrongAnswer: To facilitate further services by you or other professionals
To meet requirements of the law and of your organization
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are important reasons to document behavior services. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 2.10.

quizquestion.question: Why is it important to document behavior services you provide?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: To facilitate further services by you or other professionals
wrongAnswer: To increase billable hours that the behavior analyst may be paid for
quizquestion.explanation: To facilitate further services by you or other professionals. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 2.10.

quizquestion.question: Why is it important to document behavior services you provide?
wrongAnswer: To increase billable hours that the behavior analyst may be paid for
quizquestion.explanation: To ensure accountability. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 2.10.

quizquestion.question: Why is it important to document behavior services you provide?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: To meet requirements of the law and your organization
wrongAnswer: To increase billable hours that the behavior analyst may be paid for
quizquestion.explanation: To meet requirements of the law and your organization. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 2.10.

quizquestion.question: Which dimension of applied behavior analysis applies to the behavior analyst providing sufficient documentation that services will easily be continued when referred to another provider because of the detail in the documentation?
quizquestion.explanation: The dimension “Technological” is relevant to the situation described.

quizquestion.question: According to the BACB’s ethical code, how long are behavior analysts to keep records?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: 7 years (and as otherwise required by law)
wrongAnswer: 2 years (and as otherwise required by law)
5 years (and as otherwise required by law)
quizquestion.explanation: The BACB requires that records be stored for at least 7 years and as otherwise required by law. This is according to the BACB “Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analyst” section 2.11.

quizquestion.question: When billing for services you provide, what should you include in the billing reports?
wrongAnswer: State the nature of the services provided
State the identity of the provider
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above should be included. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 2.13

quizquestion.question: When billing for services you provide, what should you include in the billing reports?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: State the nature of the services provided
wrongAnswer: A record of billing from the past 12 months
An increase in you fees each year
quizquestion.explanation: The billing report should state the nature of the services provided. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 2.13

quizquestion.question: When billing for services you provide, what should you include in the billing reports?
wrongAnswer: A record of billing from the past 12 months
An increase in you fees each year
quizquestion.explanation: The billing report should state the fees or charges. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 2.13

quizquestion.question: When billing for services you provide, what should you include in the billing reports?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: State the identity of the provider
wrongAnswer: A record of billing from the past 12 months
An increase in you fees each year
quizquestion.explanation: The billing report should state the identity of the provider. Professional and Ethical Compliance Code for Behavior Analysts: Section 2.13

phase.name: Identify the contingencies governing the behavior of those responsible for carrying out behavior change procedures and design interventions accordingly

quizquestion.question: You have just established a behavioral goal for one of your clients. You have several staff working for you. In relation to your staff’s behavior, what might be the next task to complete?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Specify what staff must do to assist consumers in attaining desired outcomes
wrongAnswer: Train staff in the necessary skills to complete the task
quizquestion.explanation: According to “The Supervisor’s Guidebook”, there are 7 steps to a protocol for evidence-based supervision. 1. Identify desired consumer outcomes. 2. Specify what staff must do to assist consumers in attaining desired outcomes. 3. Train staff in the performance skills specified in step 2. 4. Monitor staff performance. 5. Support proficient staff performance. 6. Correnct nonprovicient staff performance. 7. Continuously evaluate staff performance.

quizquestion.question: You created a goal for one of your clients, and wrote a behavior support plan specifying what staff must do. What might be the next task to complete?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Train staff in the necessary skills to complete the task
quizquestion.explanation: According to “The Supervisor’s Guidebook”, there are 7 steps to a protocol for evidence-based supervision. 1. Identify desired consumer outcomes. 2. Specify what staff must do to assist consumers in attaining desired outcomes. 3. Train staff in the performance skills specified in step 2. 4. Monitor staff performance. 5. Support proficient staff performance. 6. Correnct nonprovicient staff performance. 7. Continuously evaluate staff performance.

quizquestion.question: You created a goal for one of your clients, wrote a behavior support plan specifying what staff must do, and trained staff in the necessary skills to complete the task. What might be the next task to complete?
wrongAnswer: Continuously evaluate staff performance and consumer outcome attainment
quizquestion.explanation: According to “The Supervisor’s Guidebook”, there are 7 steps to a protocol for evidence-based supervision. 1. Identify desired consumer outcomes. 2. Specify what staff must do to assist consumers in attaining desired outcomes. 3. Train staff in the performance skills specified in step 2. 4. Monitor staff performance. 5. Support proficient staff performance. 6. Correnct nonprovicient staff performance. 7. Continuously evaluate staff performance.

quizquestion.question: You created a goal for one of your clients, wrote a behavior support plan specifying what staff must do, and trained staff in the necessary skills to complete the task. You are monitoring staff’s performance and staff are implementing the procedure well. What might be the next task to complete?
wrongAnswer: Continuously evaluate staff performance and consumer outcome attainment
Train staff in the necessary skills to complete the task
quizquestion.explanation: According to “The Supervisor’s Guidebook”, there are 7 steps to a protocol for evidence-based supervision. 1. Identify desired consumer outcomes. 2. Specify what staff must do to assist consumers in attaining desired outcomes. 3. Train staff in the performance skills specified in step 2. 4. Monitor staff performance. 5. Support proficient staff performance. 6. Correnct nonprovicient staff performance. 7. Continuously evaluate staff performance.

quizquestion.question: You created a goal for one of your clients, wrote a behavior support plan specifying what staff must do, and trained staff in the necessary skills to complete the task. You are monitoring staff’s performance and staff are not implementing the procedure well. What might be the next task to complete?
wrongAnswer: Continuously evaluate staff performance and consumer outcome attainment
Train staff in the necessary skills to complete the task
quizquestion.explanation: According to “The Supervisor’s Guidebook”, there are 7 steps to a protocol for evidence-based supervision. 1. Identify desired consumer outcomes. 2. Specify what staff must do to assist consumers in attaining desired outcomes. 3. Train staff in the performance skills specified in step 2. 4. Monitor staff performance. 5. Support proficient staff performance. 6. Correnct nonprovicient staff performance. 7. Continuously evaluate staff performance.

quizquestion.question: You created a goal for one of your clients, wrote a behavior support plan specifying what staff must do, and trained staff in the necessary skills to complete the task. You have monitored staff’s behavior and corrected any concerns and supported appropriate performance. What might be the next task to complete?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Continuously evaluate staff performance and consumer outcome attainment
wrongAnswer: Train staff in the necessary skills to complete the task
quizquestion.explanation: According to “The Supervisor’s Guidebook”, there are 7 steps to a protocol for evidence-based supervision. 1. Identify desired consumer outcomes. 2. Specify what staff must do to assist consumers in attaining desired outcomes. 3. Train staff in the performance skills specified in step 2. 4. Monitor staff performance. 5. Support proficient staff performance. 6. Correnct nonprovicient staff performance. 7. Continuously evaluate staff performance.

quizquestion.question: How do behavioral principles apply to employees compared to clients with developmental disabilities?
wrongAnswer: Behavioral principles apply more to people with disabilities
Behavior principles apply more to employees than people with disabilities
They should not be applied to employees
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral principles apply the same to employees as with other clients.

quizquestion.question: What is a common socially mediated positive reinforcer that applies well in the workplace?
quizquestion.explanation: Praise is a common and effective socially mediated positive reinforcer that applies well in the workplace.

quizquestion.question: What is the application of behavioral principles to the workplace called?
quizquestion.explanation: OBM is the application of behavioral principles to the workplace.

quizquestion.question: Interventions used for staff should:
wrongAnswer: Use large amounts of aversive stimuli
Avoid pay, praise, and other incentives to change behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Interventions used for staff should be evidence based.

phase.name: Design and use competency based training for persons who are responsible for carry out behavioral assessment and behavior change procedures

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT a step of behavioral skills training?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Staff describe what the already know to the instructor
quizquestion.explanation: Staff do not need to discuss the skills they already know to the instructor as part of behavior skills training. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: You are training staff on how to implement planned ignore. You have described the procedure to them, and even provided a written summary of the steps. What do you do next?
wrongAnswer: Feedback is delivered, and then they go through the procedure again until they demonstrate mastery
quizquestion.explanation: The next step would be to demonstrate the target skill. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: You are training staff on how to implement planned ignore. You have described the procedure to them, and even provided a written summary of the steps. You also modeled for them how to implement planned ignore. What do you do next?
wrongAnswer: Feedback is delivered, and then they go through the procedure again until they demonstrate mastery
quizquestion.explanation: The next step would be for staff to practice the target skill. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: You are training staff on how to implement planned ignore. You have described the procedure to them, and even provided a written summary of the steps. You also modeled for them how to implement planned ignore. Staff have also practiced implementing planned ignore. What do you do next?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Feedback is delivered, and then they go through the procedure again until they demonstrate mastery
quizquestion.explanation: Feedback should be given. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: You are training staff on how to implement planned ignore. You have described the procedure to them, and even provided a written summary of the steps. You modeled for them how to implement planned ignore and then they practiced implementing planned ignore. They made several mistakes while practicing. What do you do next?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Feedback is delivered, and then they go through the procedure again until they demonstrate mastery
quizquestion.explanation: Feedback should be given. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: You are training staff on how to implement planned ignore. You have described the procedure to them, and even provided a written summary of the steps. You modeled for them how to implement planned ignore and then they practiced implementing planned ignore. They did not make any mistakes while implementing planned ignore. What do you do next?
wrongAnswer: Feedback is delivered, and then they go through the procedure again until they demonstrate mastery
quizquestion.explanation: Staff have completed training. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What is necessary before you should conduct behavior skills training?
wrongAnswer: Practice the role play prior to behavior skills training
Be able to perform the task yourself
Write down the necessary steps of the task (task analysis)
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above should take place before you conduct behavior skills training. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What is necessary before you should conduct behavior skills training?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Practice the role play prior to behavior skills training.
wrongAnswer: Know how many of the steps your staff is able to implement
All employees must already know how to implement the task
quizquestion.explanation: You should practice the role play prior to behavior skills training. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What is necessary before you should conduct behavior skills training?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Be able to perform the task yourself
wrongAnswer: Know how many of the steps your staff is able to implement
All employees must already know how to implement the task
quizquestion.explanation: You should be able to perform the task yourself. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What is necessary before you should conduct behavior skills training?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Write down the necessary steps of the task (task analysis)
wrongAnswer: Know how many of the steps your staff is able to implement
All employees must already know how to implement the task
quizquestion.explanation: You should write down the necessary steps of the task prior to conducting BST. (Reid, 2012)

phase.name: Design and use effective performance monitoring and reinforcement systems

quizquestion.question: Monitoring staff work performance:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Is essential for any effective supervisor
quizquestion.explanation: Monitoring staff work performance is essential for any effective supervisor. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: Systematically observing a designated aspect of staff work performance is:
quizquestion.explanation: Formal monitoring is when the supervisor systematically observes a designated aspect of staff work performance. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What is a possible scenario that may constitute formal monitoring of staff performance?
wrongAnswer: Staff are expected to perform new skills
Corrective action has just been taken by a supervisor
A supervisor is concerned about the quality of work of the employee
quizquestion.explanation: All answers are possible scenarios that may constitute formal monitoring of staff performance. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What is a possible scenario that may constitute formal monitoring of staff performance?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Staff were recently trained on a new skill
wrongAnswer: Staff are implementing programs without any concern
Staff are concerned about the behavior analyst’s performance
quizquestion.explanation: If staff were recently trained on a new skill, formal monitoring may be necessary. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: Making quick performance observations without using a prepared tool is:
quizquestion.explanation: Informal monitoring occurs when making quick performance observations without using a prepared tool. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What is a benefit of frequent informal monitoring?
wrongAnswer: Behavior analyst is available to staff
Increased opportunities to support proficient performance
Able to quickly respond to performance that is not proficient.
quizquestion.explanation: All answers above are benefits of frequent informal monitoring. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when staff change their behavior while they are in the presence of their supervisor:
quizquestion.explanation: Reactivity occurs when staff change their behavior while they are in the presence of their supervisor. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What is NOT an appropriate method to reduce reactivity?
wrongAnswer: Begin monitoring immediately upon entering the staff workplace
quizquestion.explanation: Covert monitoring has many problems associated with it. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: Which form of monitoring is not recommended due to possible problems?
quizquestion.explanation: Covert monitoring is not recommended because staff usually find out they are being monitored they often lose respect for the supervisor. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What can you do to make formal monitoring acceptable to staff?
wrongAnswer: Inform them ahead of time of the monitoring
Greet staff prior to the formal monitoring
quizquestion.explanation: All options provided are ways to make formal monitoring acceptable to staff. (Reid, 2012)

phase.name: Design and use systems for monitoring procedural integrity

quizquestion.question: What can you do to make formal monitoring acceptable to staff?
wrongAnswer: Inform them ahead of time of the monitoring
Greet staff prior to the formal monitoring
quizquestion.explanation: All options provided are ways to make formal monitoring acceptable to staff. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What can you do to make formal monitoring acceptable to staff?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Inform them ahead of time of the monitoring
wrongAnswer: The monitoring should take place covertly
quizquestion.explanation: Informing the staff ahead of time of the monitoring may help make monitoring more acceptable. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What can you do to make formal monitoring acceptable to staff?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Greet staff prior to the formal monitoring
wrongAnswer: The monitoring should take place covertly
quizquestion.explanation: Greet staff prior to the formal meeting will make formal monitoring more acceptable to staff. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What can you do to make formal monitoring acceptable to staff?
wrongAnswer: The monitoring should take place covertly
quizquestion.explanation: Provide feedback soon after monitoring will help make the process more acceptable to staff. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: What can you do to make formal monitoring acceptable to staff?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Acknowledge staff directly following the formal monitoring
quizquestion.explanation: Acknowledge staff directly following the formal monitoring. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: This is done to evaluate the fidelity of the independent variable:
quizquestion.explanation: Treatment integrity is evaluated to determine the fidelity of the independent variable.(Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: In practice, when there is low treatment integrity, what should take place?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Staff need to be retrained, unless another concern is evident
wrongAnswer: The client will need to be retrained
The behavior analyst will need to update the behavior intervention plan
quizquestion.explanation: Staff need to be retrained, unless another concern is evident. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the independent variable differs during implementation from the onset of the implementation.
quizquestion.explanation: Treatment drift occurs when, simply put, the intervention stops being run how it was intended to be run. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is a benefit of frequent informal monitoring?
wrongAnswer: Behavior analyst is available to staff
Increased opportunities to support proficient performance
Able to quickly respond to performance that is not proficient.
quizquestion.explanation: All answers above are benefits of frequent informal monitoring. (Reid, 2012)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when staff change their behavior while they are in the presence of their supervisor:
quizquestion.explanation: Reactivity occurs when staff change their behavior while they are in the presence of their supervisor. (Reid, 2012)

phase.name: Provide supervision for behavior change agents. Evaluate the effectiveness of the behavioral program.

quizquestion.question: Why is treatment integrity important?
wrongAnswer: Staff should learn to respect their supervisor
Staff need to develop appropriate skills
quizquestion.explanation: High treatment integrity usually results in more behavior change for the consumer. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Why is treatment integrity important?
wrongAnswer: It reduces confounds in research studies
Data are more difficult to understand
quizquestion.explanation: All of the provided answers are correct. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: What is NOT a way to increase treatment integrity?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Create a thorough and intense treatment package
wrongAnswer: Conduct behavior skills training (competency based training)
quizquestion.explanation: Interventions that are simple and standardized are more likely to be implemented correctly; however, for difficult behavior change, this is not always possible or ethical. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Your client made excellent improvements, however when treatment integrity was measured, it was very low. What does this indicate?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: You don’t know for certain that behavior change was due to your intervention
wrongAnswer: The behavior change was NOT due to your intervention
The behavior change was likely due to your intervention
Behavior change did not actually occur
quizquestion.explanation: You don’t know for certain that behavior change was due to your intervention. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Feedback to staff should most often be:
quizquestion.explanation: Feedback to staff should most often be immediate, positive, and certain

quizquestion.question: Your employee is not running the behavioral interventions consistently. He is scoring low on treatment integrity. What should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Consider the function of his behavior and other environmental variables
wrongAnswer: Retrain the employee on the skill
quizquestion.explanation: Before correcting your employee’s behavior, you should consider the function of the behavior. Is this a skill deficit, or behavior problem? Do they have skills necessary to complete the task?

quizquestion.question: You are asked to supervise a behavior analyst who wants to practice OBM, however you do not have experience in organizational behavior management. What should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Turn down the opportunity. Look for experience opportunities down the road.
wrongAnswer: Take a course on OBM before starting supervision
Take a course on OBM after starting supervision
Turn down the opportunity because you are supervising too many behavior analysts.
quizquestion.explanation: Turn down the opportunity. Look for experience opportunities down the road.

quizquestion.question: You are asked to supervise a behavior analyst, but you are already supervising several behavior analysts. This behavior analyst doesn’t have any other options, but you are too busy. What should you do?
wrongAnswer: Supervise him, otherwise he will practice without any supervision
Supervise him. You can always find time for one more supervisee
Politely decline. You do not have experience necessary to supervise him.
quizquestion.explanation: Decline the opportunity. Behavior analysts do not supervise more individuals than what allows them to be effective.

quizquestion.question: You are supervising a BCBA who does not feel confident and has not demonstrated skills in conducting discrete trials. What should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Conduct competency based training to gain more practice
wrongAnswer: Send him to conduct discrete trials without you
Go observe him conducting discrete trials
Deliver feedback that he must learn to conduct discrete trials.
quizquestion.explanation: Conduct competency based training to gain more practice if he does not have the skills to complete the task.

quizquestion.question: Reinforcement programs should be:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Designed for both Clients and employees
quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement programs should be designed for both clients and employees.

phase.name: Establish support for behavior-analytic services from direct and indirect consumers. Secure the support of others to maintain the client’s behavioral repertoires in their natural environments

quizquestion.question: This phenomenon occurs when changes in one component of a schedule results in an increase or decrease in the rate of responding but also results in the opposite effect in environments in which the schedule was not changed:
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast occurs when changes in one component of a schedule results in an increase or decrease in the rate of responding but also results in the opposite effect in environments in which the schedule was not changed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary loses TV time when her mother is home and Mary doesn’t clean her room. Mary usually cleans her room when her mother is home. When her mother is not home, Mary never cleans her room. What effect appears to be occurring?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast occurs when changes in one component of a schedule results in an increase or decrease in the rate of responding but also results in the opposite effect in environments in which the schedule was not changed. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Behavioral contrast effects can be minimized by:
wrongAnswer: Using the intervention in ALL applicable settings and conditions
Withhold reinforcement for all occurrences of problem behavior
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above can be used to minimize behavioral contrast effects. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Behavioral contrast effects can be minimized by:
wrongAnswer: Ask the person to not engage in the problem behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast effects can be minimized by providing alternative desirable behaviors. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: During a team meeting for your client, one team member is adamant about starting a treatment that is not evidence based. What is should you do?
wrongAnswer: Ask the team to take data on the effects of the treatment. If no improvement is seen, then it should be terminated.
As the BCBA, you should not implement the treatment
Ask the team member if they have any research they could provide on the effects of the treatment.
quizquestion.explanation: All of the answers above would be appropriate.

quizquestion.question: During a team meeting for your client, one team member is adamant about starting a treatment that is not evidence based. What is should you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Ask the team to take data on the effects of the treatment. If no improvement is seen, then it should be terminated.
wrongAnswer: Tell the team that you will not be part of a team that uses non-evidence based treatments
Implement your own treatment to counteract anything that the rest of the team does.
quizquestion.explanation: It would be appropriate to ask the team to take data on the effects of the treatment. If no improvement is seen, then it should be terminated.

quizquestion.question: Who is defined as a client?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Whoever benefits from the behavior analytic services provided
quizquestion.explanation: The client is whoever benefits from the behavior analytic services according to the BACB ethics code 2.0.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be identified as a “client”?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above may be identified as a client according to the BACB ethics code 2.0.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be identified as a “direct consumer”?
quizquestion.explanation: The service recipient is the direct consumer.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be identified as an “indirect consumer”?
quizquestion.explanation: All of the above are indirect consumers.

phase.name: Arrange for the orderly termination of services when they are no longer required

quizquestion.question: You are working with Ella who engages in frequent tantrums. You have worked with her for 12 months and have not seen any progress. You have changed the behavior intervention plan multiple times, but they haven’t seemed to help the behavior. What could you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Refer the client to another behavior analyst who may have more experience
wrongAnswer: Seek out a mental health diagnosis
quizquestion.explanation: Refer the client to someone who may have more experience with similar situations.

quizquestion.question: Joey is sleeping well and no longer engaging in angry outbursts. He has met the criteria established at the onset of services to discontinue services. As the behavior analyst, what do you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Terminate services by slowly fading all behavioral interventions you are providing
wrongAnswer: Immediately terminate services once the criteria are met
Look for more behaviors that would benefit from your services
Ask Joey if he wants you to leave or stay working with him
quizquestion.explanation: Terminate services once he has met the established criteria by slowly fading all behavioral interventions.

quizquestion.question: Adam is receiving behavior analysis services, but is unhappy with the service you provide. He asks for termination of services. What do you do?
wrongAnswer: Provide data to show the positive effect of your services
Provide a termination of services fee to deter him from terminating services
Provide a list of testimonials of satisfied consumers
quizquestion.explanation: It is appropriate to terminate services as requested by the client.

quizquestion.question: What is a strategy for achieving response maintenance?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Ensure the learner is coming in to contact with reinforcement from the natural environment
wrongAnswer: Tell the individual that they need to keep doing well, even when interventions are not in place
Maintain interventions present throughout the individual’s life
Slowly increase the intrusiveness of interventions, such as increasing the amount of reinforcement the individual earns.
quizquestion.explanation: Ensuring that the learner is coming in to contact with reinforcement from the natural environment will promote response maintenance. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when the learner continues to perform the target behavior after the intervention has been terminated.
quizquestion.explanation: Maintenance occurs when the learner continues to perform the target behavior after the intervention has been terminated. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Mary is a BCBA serving several clients in her area. Due to a family emergency she needs to relocate to another state for several months. Mary should:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Not abandon the clients without ensuring the cases are transferred
wrongAnswer: Do what she needs to do in emergency situations
Inform the clients that she may be able to continue services in a few months when she returns.
Resolve the family situation first, and then decide later on what to do with the caseload.
quizquestion.explanation: Mary should do everything possible to ensure the cases are transferred to a qualified replacement.

quizquestion.question: When would be an appropriate time to discontinue services with a client?
wrongAnswer: The client requests discontinuation of services
Is not benefitting from the service
Is being harmed by the service
quizquestion.explanation: It would be appropriate to discontinue services for all of the reasons listed above.

quizquestion.question: When would be an appropriate time to discontinue services with a client?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The client has met the measurable objectives laid out at the onset of services
wrongAnswer: The behavior analyst is sick, and will be unable to work for several days
The client has met one of the two measureable objectives laid out at the onset of services.
quizquestion.explanation: It would be appropriate to discontinue services if the client has met the measurable objectives laid out at the onset of services

quizquestion.question: You are hired to consult with a young boy who engages in frequent hitting. His mother wants you to help the boy learn not to hit. What might be the criterion you set to discontinue services?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: When the boy has gone 2 weeks without engaging in any hitting
wrongAnswer: When the boy has gone 12 months without engaging in any hitting
When the boy is no longer aggressive
With the boy has progressed to the point to where services are no longer needed.
quizquestion.explanation: There needs to be set criteria that includes a reasonable amount of time.

quizquestion.question: When is the most preferred situation for an individual to terminate services?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The client has met the established criterion for discontinuing services
wrongAnswer: The client requests discontinuation of services
Is not benefitting from the service
Is being harmed by the service
quizquestion.explanation: The most preferred situation for an individual to terminate services is when the client has met the established criterion for discontinuing services.

phase.name: Lawfulness of behavior, Determinism, Empiricism, Parsimony, Pragmatism

quizquestion.question: Laura has been told that high probability request sequences have been shown within the literature to increase responding to more difficult tasks. Laura thinks this is unlikely, but ultimately practices according she is demonstrating:
quizquestion.explanation: Philosophical doubt - Laura has a healthy skepticism toward information she has been provided. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is not an attitude of science recognized by behavior analysts?
quizquestion.explanation: Technological is one of the defining characteristics of ABA. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007)

quizquestion.question: I want to help my student improve his test score so I measure how often he engages in appropriate behavior (which I clearly define) during recess. This is lacking which dimension of ABA?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral dimension states that the target behavior must be socially significant. Measuring behavior during recess isn’t an effective method to improve test scores ( cooper, 16)

quizquestion.question: A parent believes that their child throws a tantrum every time in the store's candy isle because the lighting in the isle is brighter than the other isles. However, in the past the child has been given candy after throwing a tantrum in the candy isle. The second explanation for the behavior is an example of which philosophical principle of behavior analysis?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior analysts hold a pragmatic view, in that they view behavior in a practical and realistic manner as opposed to entertaining theoretical considerations.

quizquestion.question: Ida demonstrates arm flapping throughout the day. It has become more severe to the point where she has dislocated her shoulder.  The BCBA has determined that arm flapping is socially significant for Ida. Which dimension of Applied Behavior Analysis does this demonstrate?
quizquestion.explanation: “Applied” refers to the extent that behavior analysts are committed to improving behaviors that will enhance and improve people’s lives.

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT an attitude of science?
quizquestion.explanation: Correlation is not an attitude of science, although it relates to “Prediction” which is one of the purposes of science. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007 pages 5 & 6)

quizquestion.question: Which attitude of science requires the practitioner to rule out simple explanations of the phenomena prior to moving on to more complex explanations?
quizquestion.explanation: Parsimony requires the practitioner to rule out simple explanations of the phenomena prior to moving on to more complex explanations. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007 pages 5 & 6)

quizquestion.question: David is working with a child who frequently runs away. The research suggests that giving the child non-contingent breaks throughout the day may decrease this behavior. David’s opinion is that giving that break won’t be effective, despite contradicting research. David doesn’t implement the procedure. David is violating which attitude of science?
quizquestion.explanation: Empiricism is the attitude that scientists are objective in their observations, meaning they make decisions independently of their individual prejudices, tastes, and private opinions. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007 pages 5 & 6)

quizquestion.question: Behavior is lawful, in that it occurs as the result of other events. Which attitude of science is this?
quizquestion.explanation: Determinism is the attitude that the universe (including behavior) is lawful, and phenomena occur as the result of other events. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007 pages 5 & 6)

quizquestion.question: Behavior analysts are objective in their observations. Decisions are made independently of their individual prejudices, tastes, and private opinions. This is which attitude of science?
quizquestion.explanation: Empiricism is the attitude that scientists are objective in their observations, meaning they make decisions independently of their individual prejudices, tastes, and private opinions. (Cooper, Heron, Heward, 2007 pages 5 & 6)          {

quizquestion.question: All members of a species generally share the same unconditioned punishers. This is a product of:
quizquestion.explanation: Phylogeny refers to attributes that have a genetic provenance. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Selection by consequences is synonymous with:
quizquestion.explanation: Ontogeny refers to attributes (behaviors) that have formed due to the organisms learning history. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Behavior occurs and is influenced by genetics as well as the orgnasim’s learning history. Considering the provenence (source) of behavior refers to:
quizquestion.explanation: Selectionism refers to considering the provenence (source) of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Jimmy walks outside and the sun shines on his face. The bright sun elicits Jimmy’s pupils to contract. This behavior appears to have a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Unconditioned reflexes are part of the organisms genetic endowment, and relate to selectionism by phylogeny. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Sally touches a hot pan and immediately flinches her hand away. Flinching her hand away appears to have a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Unconditioned reflexes are part of the organisms genetic endowment, and relate to selectionism by phylogeny. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Kyle ate an excessive amount of food and he throws up. Throwing up occurs due to:
quizquestion.explanation: Unconditioned reflexes are part of the organisms genetic endowment, and relate to selectionism by phylogeny. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Kyle speeds while driving. Kyle is pulled over and given a ticket. From then on Kyle drives much slower (especially when a police car is present). Kyle driving slow, especially around police cars, occurs due to:
quizquestion.explanation: Ontogeny refers to attributes (behaviors) that have formed due to the organisms learning history. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Sally says “Dada” and her dad responds with high levels of praise. Sally is more likely to say “dada” in the future. Saying “dada” occurs due to:
quizquestion.explanation: Ontogeny refers to attributes (behaviors) that have formed due to the organisms learning history. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Jimmy walks outside and the sun shines on his face. Jimmy immediately places sunglasses over his eyes. Placing sunglasses over his eyes occurs due to:
quizquestion.explanation: Ontogeny refers to attributes (behaviors) that have formed due to the organisms learning history. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)

quizquestion.question: Jenny hears a loud noise and she immediately blinks her eye. Blinking her eye occurs due to:
quizquestion.explanation: Unconditioned reflexes are part of the organisms genetic endowment, and relate to selectionism by phylogeny. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 32)          {

quizquestion.question: Lyle screams when he can’t drink soda. When asked why he does this, his mother says “Lyle screams because he has oppositional defiant disorder. His mind just works differently than ours”.  In this example, the term “mind” is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Hypothetical constructs are presumed but not observed entities, such as “the mind”. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: Lyle screams when he can’t drink soda. When asked why he does this, his mother says “Lyle screams because he has oppositional defiant disorder. His mind just works differently than ours”. When asked how the mom new her son has oppositional defiant disorder, she says “Because he always screams when he can’t get what he wants”.  In this example, the mother appears to be using:
quizquestion.explanation: Circular reasoning occurs when the explanation for the behavior is the same as the description of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: Lyle screams when he can’t drink soda. When asked why he does this, his mother says “Lyle screams because he has oppositional defiant disorder”.  In this example, the mother appears to be using which type of explanation for her son’s behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Mentalistic explanations (explanatory fiction) use hypothetical constructs and circular reasoning when explaining behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: Lyle screams when he can’t drink soda. When asked why he does this, his mother says “Lyle screams because it typically results in us giving him soda”.  In this example, the mother appears to be using which type of explanation for her son’s behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Environmental explanations of behavior use observable factors that are verifiably influencing the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: Tabitha looks at the bottle of milk and says “Miiik”. You explain this behavior by saying “Tabitha says “Miiik” because she is getting so smart!” Which type of explanation does this appear to be?
quizquestion.explanation: Mentalistic explanations (explanatory fiction) use hypothetical constructs and circular reasoning when explaining behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: Tabitha looks at the bottle of milk and says “Miiik”. You explain this behavior by saying “Tabitha says “Miiik” because each approximation she makes to saying “Milk” is reinforced by Tabitha gaining access to milk.” Which type of explanation does this appear to be?
quizquestion.explanation: Environmental explanations of behavior use observable factors that are verifiably influencing the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: James is at school and frequently runs out of the classroom. The teacher explains this by saying “James runs away from the classroom because he doesn’t want to be here”. When asked how the teacher knows that James doesn’t want to be there she replies “because he is always trying to run away”. The teacher appears to be using:
quizquestion.explanation: Circular reasoning occurs when the explanation for the behavior is the same as the description of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: James is at school and frequently runs out of the classroom. The teacher explains this by saying “James runs away from the classroom because he has not yet developed the intrinsic motivation for remaining in school.” The term “Intrinsic motivation” is an example of a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Hypothetical constructs are presumed but not observed entities, such as “the mind”. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: James is at school and frequently runs out of the classroom. The teacher explains this by saying “James runs away from the classroom because he has not yet developed the intrinsic motivation for remaining in school.” The teacher appears to be using which type of explanation of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Mentalistic explanations (explanatory fiction) use hypothetical constructs and circular reasoning when explaining behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)

quizquestion.question: James is at school and frequently runs out of the classroom. The teacher explains this by saying “James runs away from the classroom because it typically results in him getting out of schoolwork.” The teacher appears to be using which type of explanation for behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Environmental explanations of behavior use observable factors that are verifiably influencing the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12)          {

quizquestion.question: Who first used the term “radical behaviorism”?
quizquestion.explanation: Skinner first used the term “Radical Behaviorism”. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: Which type of behaviorism rejects the study of private events?
quizquestion.explanation: Methodological behaviorism rejects the study of private events. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: Which type of behaviorism acknowledges the existence of mental events?
quizquestion.explanation: Both radical and methodological behaviorism acknowledges the existence of mental events. Methodological behaviorists reject to study such phenomena. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: Which type of behaviorism was prevalent prior to Skinner’s influence?
quizquestion.explanation: Methodological behaviorism rejects the study of private events. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: Which type of behaviorism was prevalent only after Skinner’s influence?
quizquestion.explanation: Radical behaviorism was prevalent only after Skinner’s influence. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: Which type of behaviorism is most prevalent today?
quizquestion.explanation: Radical behaviorism was prevalent only after Skinner’s influence, and continues to be prevalent today. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: “Radical” in “Radical Behaviorism” refers to:
quizquestion.explanation: “Radical” refers to behaviorism being far-reaching or thoroughgoing. Radical behaviorism attempts to encompass all behavior including private events. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: John is a behavior analyst under the assumption that people “Think” but he can’t observe that. John doesn’t attempt to observe or change this type of behavior. John accepts that mental events occur, but does not consider them when studying behavior. John’s behavior is most similar to:
quizquestion.explanation: Methodological behaviorism rejects the study of private events. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: John is a behavior analyst and accepts that people “think”, and engage in other mental events. John’s behavior is most similar to:
quizquestion.explanation: Both radical and methodological behaviorism acknowledges the existence of mental events. Methodological behaviorists reject to study such phenomena. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)

quizquestion.question: John is a behavior analyst and accepts that people “think”, and engage in other mental events. John does everything he can to consider these events. John is innovative in finding and studying methods to scientifically observe and understand these private events. John’s behavior is most similar to:
quizquestion.explanation: Radical behaviorism accepts that private events occur, and do what they can to scientifically study these behaviors. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 12-13)          {

phase.name: Conceptual analysis of behavior, EAB, ABA, and behavioral service delivery

quizquestion.question: Which domain of behavior analysis focuses primarily on the theory and philosophy of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Conceptual analysis of behavior primarily focuses on theory and philosophy of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: Which domain of behavior analysis has the primary goal of discovering and clarifying basic principles of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Experimental analysis of behavior focuses on discovering and clarifying basic principles of behavior, often taking place in an animal research lab. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: Which domain of behavior analysis may take place in an animal research lab?
quizquestion.explanation: Experimental analysis of behavior focuses on discovering and clarifying basic principles of behavior, often taking place in an animal research lab. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: John spends hours each day in a pigeon research lab. He uses theoretical behavior principles such as deprivation, reinforcement, and extinction to enact change in the pigeon’s behavior. John is most likely practicing in which domain of behavior analysis?
quizquestion.explanation: Experimental analysis of behavior focuses on discovering and clarifying basic principles of behavior, often taking place in an animal research lab. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: Which domain of behavior analysis conducts research while improving socially significant behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Applied behavior analysis occurs in the applied setting such as a classroom, a home, or wherever the behavior typically occurs. ABA practitioners conduct research and improve socially significant behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: Susie recently published a research article showing the behavioral methods she used to reduce self-stimulatory behavior in children with autism. Which domain of behavior analysis does this best exemplify?
quizquestion.explanation: Applied behavior analysis occurs in the applied setting such as a classroom, a home, or wherever the behavior typically occurs. ABA practitioners conduct research and improve socially significant behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: John helped a young child learn to take a bath using behavioral principles. John did not use an established program to do this, rather he created his own intervention package using evidenced based treatments found in the literature. John used a multiple probe experimental design. Which domain of behavior analysis does this best exemplify?
quizquestion.explanation: Applied behavior analysis occurs in the applied setting such as a classroom, a home, or wherever the behavior typically occurs. ABA practitioners conduct research and improve socially significant behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: Which domain of behavior analysis is the implementation of already established treatments and protocols to help make socially significant changes in behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral service delivery is the implementation of established treatments and interventions that have been shown to make socially significant changes in behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: John is an RBT, and implements the intervention designed for his specific client. John is most likely practicing in which domain of behavior analysis?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral service delivery is the implementation of established treatments and interventions that have been shown to make socially significant changes in behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)

quizquestion.question: Susie is a college professor and recently published an article regarding the unwanted effects of punishment. Susie referenced many studies throughout her article, however she did not conduct her own research. Which domain of behavior analysis does this best exemplify?
quizquestion.explanation: Conceptual analysis of behavior primarily focuses on theory and philosophy of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 21)          {

quizquestion.question: What is defined as everything a person does?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavior is defined as everything a person does. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: What is defined as one specific instance of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Response is defined as one specific instance of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: Thomas picks flowers when he goes on walks. “Picking flowers” is a:
quizquestion.explanation: Picking flowers is a behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: Thomas picked a flower while he was on a walk. This specific occurrence of the behavior is a:
quizquestion.explanation: A specific occurrence of behavior is a response. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: Thomas picks flowers with his left hand. Sometimes he picks flowers with his right hand. He even picked a flower with his toes once. All of these behaviors are topographically different but get the same result. These are an example of a:
quizquestion.explanation: A functional response class include all forms of the behavior that have the same result. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: Thomas picks flowers. He always uses his right hand, grips the plant, and pulls the plant out. Sometimes he smells the flower, sometimes he throws it away, and sometimes he gives it to his mother. This definition of “picking” includes what the behavior looks like, and has no regard to the result of the behavior. This is an example of a:
quizquestion.explanation: A topographical response class include a defined form of the behavior, and includes all responses regardless of the result of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: This is a group of responses that all take the same form, but may vary in result of the behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: A topographical response class include a defined form of the behavior, and includes all responses regardless of the result of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: This is a group of responses that may vary in form, but have the same result.
quizquestion.explanation: A functional response class include all forms of the behavior that have the same result. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT a behavior:
quizquestion.explanation: “Not” doing something is not a behavior. If a dead man can do it, then it isn’t a behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is NOT a behavior:
quizquestion.explanation: “Not” doing something is not a behavior. If a dead man can do it, then it isn’t a behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 25-26)          {

quizquestion.question: What is defined as “the conglomerate of real circumstances in which the organism exists”?
quizquestion.explanation: Environment is defined as the conglomerate of real circumstances in which the organism exists. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: What is defined as “an energy change that affects an organism through its receptor cells”?
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus is defined as an energy change that affects an organism through its receptor cells. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: What is defined as “a group of stimuli sharing a predetermined set of common elements”?
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus class is defined as a group of stimuli sharing a predetermined set of common elements. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: A stimulus class may described by all of the following EXCEPT:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus classes may be described by functionality, temporally, or formally. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: In a stimulus class, there is a green truck, a green ball, and a green candy. Which dimension do all stimuli in this class have in common?
quizquestion.explanation: The formal dimension refers to stimuli that have physical attributes in common. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: Attention from peers, access to toys, and escape from schoolwork are all part of a stimulus class, because they all may occur immediately following the child’s behavior. Which dimension do all stimuli in this class have in common?
quizquestion.explanation: The temporal dimension refers to stimuli that occur at the same time in relation to problem behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: The school bus arrives and honks the horn. The parent tells the child that it’s time to go get on the bus. The child’s alarm went off which indicates time to go to school. All of these stimuli evoke the same behavior of the child walking out of the house and on to the bus. These stimuli share which dimension to form a stimulus class?
quizquestion.explanation: The functional dimension refers to stimuli that have the same effect on behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: Your stomach aches with hunger. The oven timer goes off indicating the food is ready. You see that a fork and plate are readily available. All of these stimuli evoke the same behavior. You eat. These stimuli share which dimension to form a stimulus class?
quizquestion.explanation: The functional dimension refers to stimuli that have the same effect on behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: The basketball is available. Your opponent has their hands up trying to block your shot. The buzzer is about to go off. All of these stimuli occur prior to the behavior of shooting a ball. These stimuli share which dimension to form a stimulus class?
quizquestion.explanation: The temporal dimension refers to stimuli that occur at the same time in relation to problem behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)

quizquestion.question: There is a ball, a toy truck, and a candy within close proximity to the child. These stimuli share which dimension to form a stimulus class?
quizquestion.explanation: The formal dimension refers to stimuli that have physical attributes in common. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 27-28)          {

quizquestion.question: Sara was taught a spoken word Apple is the same as a written word Apple. She was also taught a written word Apple was same as a picture of Apple. Sara being able to give the picture of Apple to the therapist, when the therapist says “Apple” is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity occurs when A=B and B=C are trained. Then A=C is demonstrated without training. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: Stimulus equivalence is present when the client can demonstrate:
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity A=A, Symmetry A=B, B=A, Transitivity A=C. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: John was able to demonstrate that A=A, and the B=A after being taught that A=B. He was also able to demonstrate that A=C after being taught that A=B and B=A. John has demonstrated:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus equivalence is demonstrated when reflexivity, symmetry, AND transitivity have been demonstrated. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: Being able to show that A=A without prior training demonstrates which test of stimulus equivalence?
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity is demonstrating that A=A without training. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: Being able to show that B=A after being trained that A=B demonstrates which test of stimulus equivalence?
quizquestion.explanation: Symmetry is demonstrated when showing that B=A after being trained that A=B. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: Being able to show that A=C after being trained that A=B and B=C demonstrates which test of stimulus equivalence?
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity is demonstrated when showing that A=C after being trained that A=B and B=C. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a demonstration of Reflexivity?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Showing that A=A without being trained
wrongAnswer: Showing that B=A after being trained that A=B
Showing that A=C after being trained that A=B and B=C
Showing that A=A after being trained
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity is demonstrated by showing that A=A without being trained. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a demonstration of Symmetry?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Showing that B=A after being trained that A=B
wrongAnswer: Showing that A=A without being trained
Showing that A=C after being trained that A=B and B=C
Showing that A=A after being trained
quizquestion.explanation: Symmetry is demonstrated by showing that B=A after being trained that A=B. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a demonstration of transitivity?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Showing that A=C after being trained that A=B and B=C
wrongAnswer: Showing that B=A after being trained that A=B
Showing that A=A without being trained
Showing that A=A after being trained
quizquestion.explanation: Transitivity is demonstrated when showing that A=C after being trained that A=B and B=C. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)

quizquestion.question: A child is shown the written word A, then points to the written word A. This is demonstrates:
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexivity is demonstrating that A=A without training. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 398-399)          {

quizquestion.question: A loud sound elicits your eye to blink. This is unlearned behavior. This stimulus-response relation is called a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A reflex is the unlearned stimulus-response relation. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: A loud sound elicits your eye to blink. This is unlearned behavior. The loud sound is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The unconditioned stimulus is the stimulus which elicits the response without prior learning. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: A loud sound elicits your eye to blink. This is unlearned behavior. The behavior of “blinking your eye” is specifically a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The unconditioned response is the specific term for a respondent behavior whose stimulus-response relation is unlearned. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: A loud sound elicits your eye to blink. The general term for this stimulus-response behavior is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Respondent behavior is the general term for any behavior with this similar stimulus-response relation. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The temperature in the room is warm. You begin to perspire. The general term for this stimulus-response behavior is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Respondent behavior is the general term for any behavior with this similar stimulus-response relation. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The temperature in the room is warm. You begin to perspire. The behavior of perspiring is specifically a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The unconditioned response is the specific term for a respondent behavior whose stimulus-response relation is unlearned. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The temperature in the room is warm. You begin to perspire. The warm temperature is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The unconditioned stimulus is the stimulus which elicits the response without prior learning. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The temperature in the room is warm. You begin to perspire. This stimulus-response relation is called a:
quizquestion.explanation: A reflex is the unlearned stimulus-response relation. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The temperature in the room is warm. You begin to perspire. Which of the following is the unconditioned stimulus in the example?
quizquestion.explanation: The unconditioned stimulus is the stimulus which elicits the response without prior learning. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: A loud sound elicits your eye to blink. This is unlearned behavior. Which of the following is the unconditioned response?
wrongAnswer: The loud sound elicits your eye to blink
quizquestion.explanation: The unconditioned response is the specific term for a respondent behavior whose stimulus-response relation is unlearned. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)          {

quizquestion.question: John went out to dinner and ate a pulled chicken sandwich. That night, he became sick with food poisoning. Now every time John sees pulled chicken, he feels nauseous. Pulled chicken is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A conditioned stimulus is one that elicits a response as a result of respondent conditioning. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: John went out to dinner and ate a pulled chicken sandwich. That night, he became sick with food poisoning. Now every time John sees pulled chicken, he feels nauseous. “Feeling nauseous” now functions as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A conditioned response is the response in a conditioned reflex. It is elicited by a conditioned stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: John went out to dinner and ate pulled chicken sandwich. That night, he became sick with food poisoning. Now every time John sees pulled chicken, he feels nauseous. Seeing pulled chicken had never had this effect on John’s body before that night. Before that night, seeing pulled chicken was a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A neutral stimulus is one which does not elicit respondent behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: John went out to dinner and ate pulled chicken sandwich. That night, he became sick with food poisoning. Now every time John sees pulled chicken, he feels nauseous. Vomiting, that first time, is an example of a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: An unconditioned response is one which is elicited by a stimulus without prior training. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: Respondent conditioning is most effective when:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The NS is presented just before or at the same time as the US
wrongAnswer: The NS is presented at the same time or just after the US
The NS is presented a while before the US
The NS is presented a while after the US
quizquestion.explanation: Respondent conditioning is most effective when the neutral stimulus is presented just before or at the same time as the unconditioned stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: A neutral stimulus can become a conditioned stimulus by being paired with a(n):
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Either a conditioned or unconditioned stimulus
quizquestion.explanation: A neutral stimulus can be paired with either a conditioned or unconditioned stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The presentation of a loud noise elicits an accelerated heart rate. A toy is presented just before the loud noise repeatedly. Now the presentation of the toy results in an accelerated heart rate. The accelerated heart rate following the loud noise is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: An unconditioned response is one which is elicited by a stimulus without prior training. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The presentation of a loud noise elicits an accelerated heart rate. A toy is presented just before the loud noise repeatedly. Now the presentation of the toy results in an accelerated heart rate. The presentation of the loud noise is an example of a(n)
quizquestion.explanation: The presentation of the loud noise is an example of an unconditioned stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The presentation of a loud noise elicits an accelerated heart rate. A toy is presented just before the loud noise repeatedly. Now the presentation of the toy results in an accelerated heart rate. Now, the toy functions as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A conditioned stimulus is one that elicits a response as a result of respondent conditioning. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)

quizquestion.question: The procedure of repeatedly presenting a conditioned stimulus without the unconditioned stimulus until the conditioned stimulus no longer elicits the conditioned response is:
quizquestion.explanation: Respondent extinction occurs by repeatedly presenting a conditioned stimulus without the unconditioned stimulus until the conditioned stimulus no longer elicits the conditioned response. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-30)          {

quizquestion.question: Which type of behavior is made more likely or less likely based on its history of consequences?
quizquestion.explanation: Operant behavior is made more likely or less likely based on its history of consequences. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: Which type of behavior is elicited by antecedent stimuli?
quizquestion.explanation: Respondent behavior is elicited by antecedent stimuli. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: What is known as the process and selective effects of consequences on behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Operant conditioning is the process and selective effects of consequences on behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: What is known as the process of new stimuli acquiring the ability to elicit responses?
quizquestion.explanation: Respondent conditioning is known as the process of new stimuli acquiring the ability to elicit responses. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: When operant conditioning consists of an increase in response frequency, what has taken place?
