quizquestion.explanation: Reinforcement is what has taken place when operant conditioning consists of an increase in response frequency. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: In operant conditioning the stimulus change contingent on the behavior that results in an increase in that behavior is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: In operant conditioning the stimulus change contingent on the behavior that results in an increase in that behavior is known as a reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: In operant conditioning the stimulus change contingent on the behavior that results in a decrease in that behavior is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: In operant conditioning the stimulus change contingent on the behavior that results in a decrease in that behavior is known as a punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: When operant conditioning consists of a decrease in response frequency, what has taken place?
quizquestion.explanation: In operant conditioning, punishment occurs when there is a decrease in response frequency. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: Operant conditioning is most effective when:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Consequences are delivered immediately following the response
wrongAnswer: The learner is aware that their behavior was reinforced
Consequences are delivered immediately before the response
The learner is unaware of the contingency in place
quizquestion.explanation: Operant conditioning is most effective when consequences are delivered immediately following the response. Operant conditioning is effective regardless of the awareness of the learner. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)

quizquestion.question: Consequences affect:
quizquestion.explanation: Consequences affect only future behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 31-34)          {

quizquestion.question: A behavior technician presented a toy slightly before presenting a highly preferred toy, allowing for the overlap of both toys. This procedure was repeated several times. This procedure best illustrates:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus-stimulus pairing is the procedure for establishing a stimulus as a conditioned reinforcer or punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: A behavior technician presented a toy slightly before presenting a highly preferred toy, allowing for the overlap of both toys. Both toys now function as reinforcers. The toy that was a neutral stimulus before, now functions as a:
quizquestion.explanation: The toy now functions as a conditioned reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: A neutral stimulus can be made into a reinforcer by:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Pairing it with an unconditioned stimulus
wrongAnswer: Pairing it with an unconditioned response
Presenting in individually after a response multiple times
A neutral stimulus cannot be made into a reinforcer.
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus-stimulus pairing is the process of pairing a neutral stimulus, with a reinforcer or punisher, which results in the neutral stimulus acquiring the behavior altering properties of the reinforcer or punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: Behavior analysts should focus on:
quizquestion.explanation: Respondent and operant behavior are relevant to behavior analysts. Often, both behavior may occur simultaneously.  (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: You are working with a child, and have demonstrated that treats are reinforcing for the child. Praise, however, does not appear to be reinforcing. What can you do to establish praise as a reinforcer?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Deliver praise at the same time that you deliver treats as a reinforcer
wrongAnswer: Deliver praise instead of treats as a reinforcer
Deliver praise before the behavior, then deliver treats after the behavior
Deliver treats before the behavior, then deliver praise after the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Deliver praise at the same time that you deliver treats as a reinforcer. This is known as stimulus-stimulus pairing. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: You are working with a child, and have demonstrated that treats are reinforcing for the child. Praise, however, does not appear to be reinforcing. You deliver praise at the same time that you deliver treats as a reinforcer. Praise now functions as a reinforcer. Praise is now a:
quizquestion.explanation: Praise now functions as a conditioned reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: You are working with a child, and have demonstrated that treats are reinforcing for the child. Praise, however, does not appear to have any reinforcing or punishing properties. You deliver praise at the same time that you deliver treats as a reinforcer. Praise now functions as a reinforcer. Prior to stimulus-stimulus pairing, praise was a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Prior to stimulus-stimulus pairing, praise was a neutral stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: You deliver a reprimand to your supervisee, however it does not result in a decrease in inappropriate workplace behavior. If you wanted to establish reprimands as a punisher, what might you do?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Deliver a reprimand just before delivering a pay decrease
wrongAnswer: Continue delivering reprimands until they function as a punisher
Focus on increasing appropriate replacement behavior through positive reinforcement
Deliver reprimands on a delayed schedule, at least 1 day following the behavior
quizquestion.explanation: Positive reinforcement should always be used (especially in the work place!) However that wasn’t the question. If you wanted to establish reprimands as a punisher, it should be paired with a punisher (such as a pay decrease). (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: You deliver a reprimand to your supervisee, however it does not result in a decrease in inappropriate workplace behavior. Reprimands do not appear to function as a reinforcer or punisher. You pair reprimands with a pay decrease, and reprimands now function as a punisher. Prior to stimulus-stimulus pairing, reprimands functioned as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Prior to stimulus-stimulus pairing, reprimand was a neutral stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)

quizquestion.question: You deliver a reprimand to your supervisee, however it does not result in a decrease in inappropriate workplace behavior. Reprimands do not appear to function as a reinforcer or punisher. You pair reprimands with a pay decrease, and reprimands now function as a punisher. Reprimands now function as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: reprimands now function as a conditioned punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 29-37)          {

quizquestion.question: You are teaching your dog basic commands like sit, stay, come and give paw. Each time he correctly displays the command, you provide him with a treat. This increases those appropriate responses. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of positive reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a common example of a stimulus that may function as an unconditioned positive reinforcer?
quizquestion.explanation: Food is a common example of a stimulus that may function as an unconditioned positive reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a common example of a stimulus that may function as an unconditioned positive reinforcer?
quizquestion.explanation: Warmth is a stimulus that may function as an unconditioned positive reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a common example of a stimulus that may function as an unconditioned negative reinforcer?
quizquestion.explanation: Removal of pain is an unconditioned negative reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a common example of a stimulus that may function as an unconditioned negative reinforcer?
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The termination of a loud noise
quizquestion.explanation: The termination of a loud noise is a stimulus that may function as an unconditioned negative reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: All of the following are unconditioned reinforcers except:
quizquestion.explanation: Pain is not an unconditioned reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: What has occurred when behavior has increased due to the delivery of consequences that have no particular learning history?
quizquestion.explanation: Unconditioned reinforcement occurs when behavior increases due to the delivery of consequences that have no particular learning history. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: Joe has a headache and takes Ibuprofen. The headache goes away. Joe is more likely to take Ibuprofen in the future when he has a headache. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of negative reinforcement. The pain goes away, which increases the likelihood of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: What has occurred when behavior has increased due to the delivery of consequences that have acquired reinforcing properties through a learning history.
quizquestion.explanation: Conditioned reinforcement occurs when behavior increases due to the delivery of consequences that have acquired reinforcing properties through a learning history. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)

quizquestion.question: Joe is cold and puts a blanket around him. Joe is now a comfortable temperature, and is more likely to put a blanket around him when he is cold. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Wearing a blanket adds heat, and reinforced the behavior. This is positive reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269)          {

quizquestion.question: A child and his mother are at the store. The child sees a toy he wants. He screams. His mother is embarrassed that everyone around her is staring, so buys the toy. He stops screaming and people stop staring. The mother is more likely to buy a toy when the child screams in the store in the future because of:
quizquestion.explanation: The contingency influencing the mother is negative reinforcement. The child stopped crying, which increased the likelihood that the mom would do this again. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: A child is constantly crying. His mother offers him a lollipop to stop crying. The child stops. What kind of reinforcement is reinforcing the mother behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: The contingency influencing the mother is negative reinforcement. The child stopped crying, which increased the likelihood that the mom would do this again. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: Mrs. Smith has a dog. Every time the dog sits when she says “sit” she gives him a treat. In the future, her dog sits more often every time she says “sit.” This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of positive reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: A parent wants to deliver a sticker to Ryan every time he says “Please.” This would be considered positive reinforcement if:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: The behavior of saying “Please” increases over time.
wrongAnswer: The behavior of saying “Please” decreases over time.
The behavior of saying “Please” does not change over time.
The behavior of sticker giving decreases over time.
quizquestion.explanation: A stimulus is a reinforcer only if the behavior for which it was delivered contingently increases in the future. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: Bob gets put in the timeout room each time he yells in the classroom. In the future, the frequency of yelling increases. In this case, the timeout room is functioning as:
quizquestion.explanation: The intervention was likely in place to decrease the behavior, but it appears to be reinforcing the behavior instead. This is an example of negative reinforcement because he is removed from the class and the behavior increases. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a conditioned reinforcer?
quizquestion.explanation: Money is a conditioned reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a conditioned reinforcer?
quizquestion.explanation: Praise is an example of a conditioned reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: What is defined as a reinforcer that as a result of being paired with many reinforcers it does not depend on a current EO for any particular form of reinforcement for its effectiveness?
quizquestion.explanation: A generalize conditioned reinforcer is a reinforcer that as a result of being paired with many reinforcers it does not depend on a current EO for any particular form of reinforcement for its effectiveness. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an example of a generalized conditioned reinforcer?
quizquestion.explanation: A generalize conditioned reinforcer is a reinforcer that as a result of being paired with many reinforcers it does not depend on a current EO for any particular form of reinforcement for its effectiveness. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an example of a generalized conditioned reinforcer?
quizquestion.explanation: A generalize conditioned reinforcer is a reinforcer that as a result of being paired with many reinforcers it does not depend on a current EO for any particular form of reinforcement for its effectiveness. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 269-274)          {

quizquestion.question: What is a stimulus that can decrease the future frequency of a behavior that precedes it without prior pairing with other punishers?
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of an unconditioned punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-337)

quizquestion.question: Jerry has enuresis where he often wets the bed. The behavior analyst uses a urine alarm where when it senses wetness, it wakes him up with a loud beep. The loud beep decreases the future frequency of wetting the bed, and is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Positive punishment occurs when a stimulus is added which decreases the future frequency of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-337)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following are not negative side effects of punishment?
quizquestion.explanation: Aversive control is a term used to mean any form of punishment or negative reinforcement (any application of aversive stimulation). (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-337)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following stimuli may function as an unconditioned punisher?
quizquestion.explanation: All answers provided are stimuli that may function as an unconditioned punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-337)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following stimuli may function as an unconditioned punisher?
quizquestion.explanation: Extreme muscular effort may function as an unconditioned punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-337)

quizquestion.question: Sally is experiencing pain in her foot, until she moves her foot away from her dog who is nibbling on her toes. Sally is more likely to move her foot in a similar situation in the future. This contingency is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of negative reinforcement. There was an increase in the future likelihood of the behavior.

quizquestion.question: Sally sets her foot down next to her dog, who begins nibbling on her toes. Sally is less likely to put her foot down in front of her dog in the future. This contingency is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Pain in the foot was added when she placed her foot near the dog. This made her less likely to do so in the future. This is positive punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-337)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when an aversive stimulus is removed contingent on the person’s behavior, which results in an increased likelihood of engaging in that behavior again.
quizquestion.explanation: Negative reinforcement occurs when an aversive stimulus is removed contingent on the person’s behavior, which results in an increased likelihood of engaging in that behavior again.

quizquestion.question: This occurs when an appetitive stimulus is removed contingent on the person’s behavior, which results in a decreased likelihood of engaging in that behavior again.
quizquestion.explanation: Negative punishment occurs when an appetitive stimulus is removed contingent on the person’s behavior, which results in a decreased likelihood of engaging in that behavior again. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-337)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when an aversive stimulus is delivered contingent on the person’s behavior, which results in a decreased likelihood of engaging in that behavior again.
quizquestion.explanation: Positive punishment occurs when an aversive stimulus is delivered contingent on the person’s behavior, which results in a decreased likelihood of engaging in that behavior again. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-337)          {

quizquestion.question: David raised his hand in class to volunteer to help. The teacher enthusiastically praised David, “You are awesome!  Such a fine young boy who is always willing to help!”  In the future, David's handraising to volunteer decreases. The teacher’s praise appears to function as a:
quizquestion.explanation: The teacher was likely attempting positive reinforcement, but praise for this child had the opposite effect on the child’s behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: Which one is not a form of non-exclusionary time out?
quizquestion.explanation: Partition time out is a form exclusionary time out. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: After determining it necessary, Raquel has started removing a token from Matthew’s board every time he engages in aggression towards others. Following this intervention, Matthew’s aggression has decreased. Raquel is implementing
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of a response cost. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: Ian was reading a book in the doctors waiting room. A lady approached him and began talking to him about his book. From now on when he is in a waiting room he does not read books. This contingency is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: This is an example of positive punishment. The negative attention that Ian received was a stimulus added which decreased the frequency of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: Michael threw a paper on the school playground. The teacher then told him to pick the paper and throw it in the garbage and  also collect all the other papers from the school playground. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Restitutional overcorrection takes place be requiring the learner to repair the damage from caused by the behavior, and also improving the environment to a better standard than where it was prior to the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may function as a conditioned punisher?
quizquestion.explanation: Pain, loud noise, and physical restraint are all primary punishers. Praise, on the other hand, may unintentionally be conditioned to be a punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: Lucy engages in frequent physical aggression. After trying more positive interventions, you decide to include reprimands as punishment. Reprimands do not seem to have a reinforcing or punishing effect on Lucy’s behavior. You use a reprimand just before putting Lucy in time out, until reprimands function as punishers. Prior to being paired with time out, reprimands appear to have functioned as:
quizquestion.explanation: Prior to being paired with time out, reprimands appear to have functioned as a neutral stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: Lucy engages in frequent physical aggression. After trying more positive interventions, you decide to include reprimands as punishment. Reprimands do not seem to have a reinforcing or punishing effect on Lucy’s behavior. You use a reprimand just before putting Lucy in time out, until reprimands function as punishers. After being paired with time out, reprimands functioned as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Conditioned punishers are those that have been paired with a punisher to establish its punishing effect. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: Lucy engages in frequent physical aggression. After trying more positive interventions, you decide to include reprimands as punishment. Reprimands do not seem to have a reinforcing or punishing effect on Lucy’s behavior. You use a reprimand just before putting Lucy in time out, until reprimands function as punishers. The process of establishing reprimands as a punisher is called:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus-stimulus pairing is the process of pairing a punisher or reinforcer with a neutral stimulus to give that stimulus its punishing/reinforcing effect. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)

quizquestion.question: Lucy engages in frequent physical aggression. After trying more positive interventions, you decide to include reprimands as punishment. With this contingency in place, there was no apparent increase or decrease in the frequency of physical aggression. What is the best description of the contingency in place:
quizquestion.explanation: Neither reinforcement nor punishment are occurring because there was no change in the future frequency of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 327-371)          {

quizquestion.question: Sean put himself on a reinforcement study schedule. After every 15 powerpoint slides of studying, he allowed himself 3 minutes of social media. This is an example of
quizquestion.explanation: Fixed ratio schedule delivers reinforcement contingent on a set number of responses. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: The school teacher delivers the student a break from school work after exactly 1 hour since their last break. Before taking another break they must complete at least one problem on their assignment. What is this schedule of reinforcement?
quizquestion.explanation: Fixed interval schedules deliver reinforcement after the first response after an exact duration time. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: Which schedule of reinforcement typically has a graph with a scallop between delivery of reinforcement?
quizquestion.explanation: Fixed interval schedules typically have a graph that includes a scallop while waiting for reinforcement to be available. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: The school teacher delivers the student a break from school work after around 1 hour since their last break. Sometimes it’s 55 min, and sometimes it’s just over an hour. Before taking another break they must complete at least one problem on their assignment. What is this schedule of reinforcement?
quizquestion.explanation: The variable interval schedule delivers reinforcement after the first response after variable durations of time. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: The BCBA delivers praise after every correct response. Which schedule of reinforcement is this?
quizquestion.explanation: Continuous reinforcement (CRF) is the delivery of reinforcement for every correct response (FR1). (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: The BCBA delivers praise after 1 correct response, and sometimes he delivers praise every 3 or 4 correct responses. It is generally about every 2 correct responses, reinforcement is delivered. What is this schedule of reinforcement?
quizquestion.explanation: Variable ratio schedules of reinforcement deliver reinforcement following a variable number of responses. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following compound schedules of reinforcement does NOT have a clear discriminative stimulus?
quizquestion.explanation: Mixed and Tandem schedules of reinforcement do NOT have a clear discriminative stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following compound schedules of reinforcement has a clear discriminative stimulus?
quizquestion.explanation: A multiple schedule does have a clear discriminative stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: Which schedule of reinforcement relates most to the Matching Law?
quizquestion.explanation: The concurrent schedule of reinforcement relates most to the matching law. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following schedules combines the number of responses and time?
quizquestion.explanation: Both alternative and conjunctive schedules of reinforcement combine the number of responses and time. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 305-322)          {

quizquestion.question: A procedure in which reinforcement for a previously reinforced behavior is no longer followed by reinforcement, resulting in a decrease in the future frequency of that behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction occurs when which reinforcement for a previously reinforced behavior is no longer followed by reinforcement, resulting in a decrease in the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: What is a brief increase in the frequency in responding when extinction is initially implemented?
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction bursts often occur when there is an increase in the behavior when extinction is initially implemented. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: Michael is given attention every time he engages in angry outbursts. His family begins to ignore Michael whenever he engages in angry outbursts. At first, his angry outbursts increase, but then they begin to decrease, to the point where Michael no longer engages in angry outbursts. One day, after not engaging in the behavior for weeks, Michael engages in angry outbursts. What procedure did Michael’s family implement to make angry outbursts decrease?
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction occurs when which reinforcement for a previously reinforced behavior is no longer followed by reinforcement, resulting in a decrease in the future frequency of that behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: Michael is given attention every time he engages in angry outbursts. His family begins to ignore Michael whenever he engages in angry outbursts. At first, his angry outbursts increase, but then they begin to decrease, to the point where Michael no longer engages in angry outbursts. One day, after not engaging in the behavior for weeks, Michael engages in angry outbursts. What is the term to describe the initial increase in angry outbursts that Michael experienced?
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction bursts often occur when there is an increase in the behavior when extinction is initially implemented. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: Michael is given attention every time he engages in angry outbursts. His family begins to ignore Michael whenever he engages in angry outbursts. At first, his angry outbursts increase, but then they begin to decrease, to the point where Michael no longer engages in angry outbursts. One day, after not engaging in the behavior for weeks, Michael engages in angry outbursts. What is the term to describe the occurrence of angry outbursts after weeks without concern?
quizquestion.explanation: Spontaneous recovery occurs when the behavior of concern returns after extinction has taken place. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: Michael is given attention every time he engages in angry outbursts. His family begins to ignore Michael whenever he engages in angry outbursts. At first, his angry outbursts increase, but then they begin to decrease, to the point where Michael no longer engages in angry outbursts. One day, after not engaging in the behavior for weeks, Michael engages in angry outbursts. What was maintaining the angry outbursts from the beginning?
quizquestion.explanation: Michael was receiving attention whenever he engaged in angry outbursts. This is positive reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: Sara would curse while at school, which would result in her getting out of school work. Her teacher began requiring her to complete her school work even when she would curse. Sara began cursing more, initially, but then the behavior quickly decreased. The behavior hadn’t happened for days, when Sara began cursing. What was maintaining Sara’s cursing from the beginning?
quizquestion.explanation: Negative reinforcement was occurring, because Sara would get out of school work (removal of a stimulus) which resulted in an increase of swearing. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: Sara would curse while at school, which would result in her getting out of school work. Her teacher began requiring her to complete her school work even when she would curse. Sara began cursing more, initially, but then the behavior quickly decreased. The behavior hadn’t happened for days, when Sara began cursing. What procedure did the school teacher implement?
quizquestion.explanation: The school teacher implemented extinction by not allowing Sara to get out of her school work. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: Sara would curse while at school, which would result in her getting out of school work. Her teacher began requiring her to complete her school work even when she would curse. Sara began cursing more, initially, but then the behavior quickly decreased. The behavior hadn’t happened for days, when Sara began cursing. What is the term to describe the initial increase in cursing, when the teacher required school work completion?
quizquestion.explanation: Extinction bursts often occur when there is an increase in the behavior when extinction is initially implemented. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)

quizquestion.question: Sara would curse while at school, which would result in her getting out of school work. Her teacher began requiring her to complete her school work even when she would curse. Sara began cursing more, initially, but then the behavior quickly decreased. The behavior hadn’t happened for days, when Sara began cursing. What is the term to describe the occurrence of swearing after days of no cursing?
quizquestion.explanation: Spontaneous recovery occurs when the behavior of concern returns after extinction has taken place. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 457-467)          {

quizquestion.question: Ashley loves tequila!  Every time Ashley takes a few shots of tequila, she gets a nice warm, fuzzy feeling.  As a result, Ashley takes more shots.  This best describes:
quizquestion.explanation: This behavior did not require another person. It was automatic positive reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: The boy runs fast down the hill. He falls down and scratches his knee. He is not as likely to run down hills in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: The boy did not require another person to deliver the stimulus of pain. This was automatic positive punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: The boy runs fast down the hill. His mother scolds him for being reckless. The boy is not as likely to run down hills in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Another person delivered the aversive stimulus (scold), which decreased behavior. This is socially mediated positive punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: The boy runs fast down the hill. His mother immediately takes away his favorite toy that he is holding. The boy is less likely to run down hills in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Another person removed a stimulus, decreasing the behavior. This is socially mediated negative punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: The boy runs fast down the hill. He drops his favorite toy which gets lost. The boy is less likely to run down hills in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Another person was not involved, but a stimulus was removed (his toy was lost).This is automatic negative punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: The removal of an aversive stimulus without another person present, that increases the likelihood that the preceding behavior will occur again in the future is:
quizquestion.explanation: Automatic negative reinforcement occurs when the removal of an aversive stimulus without another person present, that increases the likelihood that the preceding behavior will occur again in the future. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: Thomas sees his friend’s wallet unattended. Thomas takes $20 while his friend isn’t looking. Thomas is likely to do this again in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: The friend was not present, and the stimulus was added (money). This is automatic positive reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: Thomas asks his friend for $20. His friend pays up. Thomas is more likely to ask his friend again in the future. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: The friend was present, and delivered the stimulus. This is socially mediated positive reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: Thomas has an itch on his back. He reaches and is able to relieve the sensation. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Thomas was able to remove the itching sensation by scratching his own back. This is automatic negative reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)

quizquestion.question: Thomas has an itch on his back. He asks his friend to scratch his back. His friend does, and the itching sensation goes away. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Thomas was able to have his friend scratch his back, and the aversive stimulus was removed. This is an example of socially mediated negative reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 534-536)          {

phase.name: Stimulus control, stimulus discrimination, & conditional discriminations

quizquestion.question: Which term describes a stimulus that indicates the availability of reinforcement:
quizquestion.explanation: SD describes a stimulus that indicates the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Which term describes a stimulus that indicates the unavailability of reinforcement?
quizquestion.explanation: The SΔ is a term for a stimulus that indicates the unavailability of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Which term describes a stimulus that indicates the availability of punishment?
quizquestion.explanation: The SDP is a stimulus that indicates the availability of punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Which term describes a stimulus that indicates the unavailability of punishment?
quizquestion.explanation: The SΔP is a stimulus that indicates the unavailability of punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following will establish stimulus control?
quizquestion.explanation: Although extinction and reinforcement are essential components to stimulus discrimination training, alone, extinction or reinforcement will not establish stimulus control. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Elaine is given $.25 whenever she asks her grandfather for money. Seeing her grandfather indicates that reinforcement is available. However, when her grandmother is present, Elaine is put in time out for asking for money, which has decreased the frequency of asking for money in her grandmother’s presence. Her grandfather appears to be an:
quizquestion.explanation: SD describes a stimulus that indicates the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Elaine is given $.25 whenever she asks her grandfather for money. Seeing her grandfather indicates that reinforcement is available, when he is absent, reinforcement is unavailable. However, when her grandmother is present, Elaine is put in time out for asking for money, which has decreased the frequency of asking for money in her grandmother’s presence. The grandfather’s absence appears to be an:
quizquestion.explanation: The SΔ is a term for a stimulus that indicates the unavailability of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Elaine is given $.25 whenever she asks her grandfather for money. Seeing her grandfather indicates that reinforcement is available. However, when her grandmother is present, Elaine is put in time out for asking for money, which has decreased the frequency of asking for money in her grandmother’s presence. The grandmother’s absence is likely an:
quizquestion.explanation: The SΔP is a stimulus that indicates the unavailability of punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Elaine is given $.25 whenever she asks her grandfather for money. Seeing her grandfather indicates that reinforcement is available. However, when her grandmother is present, Elaine is put in time out for asking for money, which has decreased the frequency of asking for money in her grandmother’s presence. The grandmother’s absence is likely an:
quizquestion.explanation: The SDP is a stimulus that indicates the availability of punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)

quizquestion.question: Elaine is given $.25 whenever she asks her grandfather for money. Seeing her grandfather indicates that reinforcement is available. However, when her grandfather is absent, reinforcement is not available. Elaine’s grandfather appears to have:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus control is when the antecedent stimulus alters the response reate, latency, duration, or amplitude of a response. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 393-396)          {

phase.name: Multiple functions of a single stimulus

quizquestion.question: In a behavior chain, the SD for the second behavior is usually the ________ for the first behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: In a behavior chain, the SD for the second behavior is usually the reinforcer for the first behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: In a behavior chain, the reinforcer for the second behavior is usually the ______ for the third behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: In a behavior chain, the reinforcer for the second behavior is usually the SD for the third behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: Frank opens his fridge and sees a Coke. He grabs the Coke and closes the fridge. He opens the can and hears the “pop”. He then brings the can to his mouth and drinks the coke. The sound “pop” is likely reinforcing which behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: The “pop” is likely reinforcing the behavior that occurred just before it, which was opening the can. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: Frank opens his fridge and sees a Coke. He grabs the Coke and closes the fridge. He opens the can and hears the “pop”. He then brings the can to his mouth and drinks the coke. The sound “pop” is likely the SD for which behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: hearing “pop” is likely the SD for drinking the Coke. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: Frank opens his fridge and sees a Coke. He grabs the Coke and closes the fridge. He opens the can and hears the “pop”. He then brings the can to his mouth and drinks the coke. Seeing the Coke in the fridge is likely reinforcing which behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Opening the fridge is likely being reinforced by seeing the Coke. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: Frank opens his fridge and sees a Coke. He grabs the Coke and closes the fridge. He opens the can and hears the “pop”. He then brings the can to his mouth and drinks the coke. Seeing the Coke in the fridge is likely the SD for which behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Seeing the drink in the fridge is likely the SD for grabbing the Coke. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: Jessica hears the doorbell and she opens the door. Her friend is outside and asks if Jessica wants to play. Jessica says “yes”. Her friend says “let’s play outside”. They both go outside and play in their front yard. Seeing her friend outside the door and asking Jessica to play is likely reinforcing which behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Opening the door took place just before seeing her friend. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: Jessica hears the doorbell and she opens the door. Her friend is outside and asks if Jessica wants to play. Jessica says “yes”. Her friend says “let’s play outside”. They both go outside and play in their front yard. Seeing her friend outside the door and asking Jessica to play is likely an SD for which behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Saying “yes” took place right after her friend asked if she wants to play. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: Jessica hears the doorbell and she opens the door. Her friend is outside and asks if Jessica wants to play. Jessica says “yes”. Her friend says “let’s play outside”. They both go outside and play in their front yard. Her friend saying “let’s play outside” is likely reinforcing which behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Her friend said “let’s play outside” immediately after Jessica said “yes”. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)

quizquestion.question: Jessica hears the doorbell and she opens the door. Her friend is outside and asks if Jessica wants to play. Jessica says “yes”. Her friend says “let’s play outside”. They both go outside and play in their front yard. Her friend saying “let’s play outside” is likely an SD for which behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: They went outside right after the friend said “let’s play outside”. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 435-441)          {

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is an unconditioned motivating operation:
wrongAnswer: The presence of an abusive parent
quizquestion.explanation: An increase in painful stimulation is the only example of a UMO present. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is not a type of conditioned motivating operation?
quizquestion.explanation: Symmetry CMO is not a type of CMO. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: Joseph is hungry which increases the value of food as a reinforcer. Hunger in this example appears to be a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: An establishing operation increases the value of a stimulus as a reinforcer or punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: What increases the value of a stimulus as a reinforcer or punisher?
quizquestion.explanation: An establishing operation increases the value of a stimulus as a reinforcer. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: What decreases the value of a stimulus as a reinforcer or punisher?
quizquestion.explanation: An abolishing operation decreases the value of a stimulus as a reinforcer or punisher. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: Joseph warms up when the sun comes up while camping. The reinforcing value of warmth is decreased. This is an example of a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: An abolishing operation is resent with the reinforcing value of a stimulus is decreased. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: Establishing operations are a type of:
quizquestion.explanation: Establishing operations are a type of motivating operations. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: Joseph is hungry which increases the value of food as a reinforcer. Hunger in this example appears to be a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Hunger is an unconditioned motivating operation. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: Joseph warms up when the sun comes up while camping. The reinforcing value of warmth is decreased. This is an example of a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Warmth is an unconditioned motivating operation. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)

quizquestion.question: Joseph is standing outside and he sees a bee. The sight of the bee increases the value of a shoe to be able to smash the bee. The sight of the bee is functioning as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The sight of the bee increases the value of the shoe as a reinforcer. This is a learned MO. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375-390)          {

quizquestion.question: Which of the following establishes value altering properties by being temporally paired with an unconditioned motivating operation?
quizquestion.explanation: Surrogate CMO’s gain their value altering properties by being temporally paired with an unconditioned motivating operation. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: Which type of motivating operation has been paired with an aversive stimulus, and now functions as a warning stimulus?
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexive CMOs act as warning stimuli and have been paired with aversive stimuli in the past. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: Which type of motivating operation establishes the reinforcing effectiveness of another stimulus and evokes the behavior that has been reinforced by that other stimulus?
quizquestion.explanation: The transitive CMO establishes the reinforcing effectiveness of another stimulus and evokes the behavior that has been reinforced by that other stimulus. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: You usually watch a cooking show when you are hungry, then you go and make some food. Today, you watch the cooking show right after a meal, however, due to the learning history, you still get up to go cook food. What type of motivating operation does the cooking show appear to be?
quizquestion.explanation: Surrogate CMO’s gain their value altering properties by being temporally paired with an unconditioned motivating operation. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: You give your child a stuffed animal right before he goes to bed every night. You drive in the car one morning, and give him the stuffed animal. He closes his eyes and tries to go to sleep. The stuffed animal appears to be functioning as which type of MO?
quizquestion.explanation: Surrogate CMO’s gain their value altering properties by being temporally paired with an unconditioned motivating operation. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: You are outside and see a bee close by. The bee increases the value of the bee going away as a reinforcer. You see a shoe, grab it, and swat the bee to go away. What type of motivating operation is the bee?
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexive CMOs act as warning stimuli and have been paired with aversive stimuli in the past. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: Jessica lives in a group home. Many times Jessica has seen staff completing paperwork, and then staff reprimand Jessica for inappropriate behavior. Now, whenever Jessica sees staff completing paperwork she runs over and rips up the paperwork. The sight of staff completing paperwork increases the value of removing paperwork. The sight of staff completing paperwork now functions as what type of CMO?
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexive CMOs act as warning stimuli and have been paired with aversive stimuli in the past. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: You purchase a drink from a fast food restaurant. The drink has a lid, which requires a straw. The sight of the drink and lid increases the value of the straw as reinforcement, making the sight of the drink with the lid which type of MO?
quizquestion.explanation: The transitive CMO establishes the reinforcing effectiveness of another stimulus and evokes the behavior that has been reinforced by that other stimulus. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: A “Battery Low” message appears on your phone. Removing that message is important to you, so you plug in your phone. The “Battery Low” message appears to be which type of MO?
quizquestion.explanation: Reflexive CMOs act as warning stimuli and have been paired with aversive stimuli in the past. The removal of the CMO-R is reinforcing. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)

quizquestion.question: While trying to charge your phone, you see the USB to micro USB cord, but do not see the wall plug-in piece. Seeing the USB cord without the wall plug-in piece increases the value of the wall plug in piece, making the cord which type of MO?
quizquestion.explanation: The transitive CMO establishes the reinforcing effectiveness of another stimulus and evokes the behavior that has been reinforced by that other stimulus. (Cooper et al., p. 384-389)          {

quizquestion.question: You are hungry and see a bucket of fried chicken in your kitchen. You grab a piece and thoroughly enjoy eating it. Being hungry is a:
quizquestion.explanation: MOs alter the value of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: You are hungry and see a bucket of fried chicken in your kitchen. You grab a piece and thoroughly enjoy eating it. The sight of the bucket of chicken is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The SD signals the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: You are hungry and see a bucket of fried chicken in your kitchen. You grab a piece and thoroughly enjoy eating it. For the contingency described, eating the chicken is likely the:
quizquestion.explanation: The reinforcer is the last piece of a contingency, and is the appetitive stimulus which makes the behavior more likely to occur in the future. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: You are outside and see a dog posturing as if to attack. You see a rock on the ground. You bend down to pick up the rock, and as you do so the dog gets scared and runs away. In this 4 term contingency, the sight of the dog appears to be a:
quizquestion.explanation: MOs alter the value of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: You are outside and see a dog posturing as if to attack. You see a rock on the ground. You bend down to pick up the rock, and as you do so the dog gets scared and runs away. In this 4 term contingency, the sight of the rock appears to be a:
quizquestion.explanation: The SD signals the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)          {

quizquestion.question: You are outside and see a dog posturing as if to attack. You see a rock on the ground. You bend down to pick up the rock, and as you do so the dog gets scared and runs away. In this 4 term contingency, the dog running away is likely a:
quizquestion.explanation: The reinforcer is the last piece of a contingency, and is the appetitive stimulus which makes the behavior more likely to occur in the future. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: You are outside and see a dog posturing as if to attack. You see a rock on the ground. You bend down to pick up the rock, and as you do so the dog gets scared and runs away. In this 4 term contingency, picking up the rock is the:
quizquestion.explanation: Picking up the rock is a behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: While teaching a child to mand, you make sure he hasn't had food in 2 hours to ensure he is hungry. You have the cookie in sight and say “what would you like?” The child says “Cookie”. You give the child a piece of the cookie. In this 4 term contingency, food deprivation is a:
quizquestion.explanation: MOs alter the value of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: While teaching a child to mand, you make sure he hasn't had food in 2 hours to ensure he is hungry. You have the cookie in sight and say “what would you like?” The child says “Cookie”. You give the child a piece of the cookie. In this 4 term contingency, the sight of the cookie is a:
quizquestion.explanation: The SD signals the availability of reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: While teaching a child to mand, you make sure he hasn't had food in 2 hours to ensure he is hungry. You have the cookie in sight and say “what would you like?” The child says “Cookie”. You give the child a piece of the cookie. In this 4 term contingency, saying “cookie” is a:
quizquestion.explanation: Saying “cookie” is a behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 377)

quizquestion.question: In relation to motivating operations, the increase in reinforcing effectiveness of some stimulus is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A value-altering effect refers to the increase in reinforcing effectiveness of some stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: In relation to motivating operations, the increase or decrease in the current frequency of behavior is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The behavior-altering effect refers to the increase or decrease in the current frequency of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: In relation to motivating operations, the increase in the current frequency of behavior is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The evocative effect refers to an increase in the current frequency of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: In relation to motivating operations, the decrease in current frequency of behavior is a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The abative effect refers to the decrease in current frequency of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: You are hungry and see a bucket of fried chicken in your kitchen. You grab a piece and thoroughly enjoy eating it. You being hungry increased the frequency of eating chicken. This effect is referred to as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The evocative effect refers to an increase in the current frequency of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: You are hungry and see a bucket of fried chicken in your kitchen. You grab a piece and thoroughly enjoy eating it. You being hungry increased the value of chicken as a reinforcer. This effect is referred to as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A value-altering effect refers to the increase or decrease in reinforcing effectiveness of some stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: You just ate food and are no longer hungry. You walk in to your kitchen and see a bucket of chicken. You do not eat the chicken. Being satiated on food decreased the value of chicken as a reinforcer. This effect is referred to as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A value-altering effect refers to the increase or decrease in reinforcing effectiveness of some stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: You just ate food and are no longer hungry. You walk in to your kitchen and see a bucket of chicken. You do not eat the chicken. Being satiated on food decreased the current frequency of eating chicken. This effect is referred to as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The abative effect refers to the decrease in current frequency of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: You are outside and see a dog posturing as if to attack. You pick up a rock, and as you do so the dog gets scared and runs away. The sight of a posturing dog increases the current frequency of picking up a rock. This effect is known as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: The evocative effect refers to an increase in the current frequency of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)

quizquestion.question: You are outside and see a dog posturing as if to attack. You pick up a rock, and as you do so the dog gets scared and runs away. The sight of a posturing dog increases the value of the rock as a reinforcer. This effect is known as a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: A value-altering effect refers to the increase or decrease in reinforcing effectiveness of some stimulus. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 375)          {

quizquestion.question: The 4 term contingency refers to:
quizquestion.explanation: The 4 term contingency refers to MO, SD, Response, and Reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: The 3 term contingency refers to:
quizquestion.explanation: The 3 term contingency refers to antecedent, response (or behavior), consequence. Consequence is a better term than reinforcement because it also include punishment. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following reflects the main four functions of behavior commonly recognized among behavior analysts?
quizquestion.explanation: The four common functions of behavior commonly recognized among behavior analysts include attention, automatic (sensory), escape, and tangible (access). (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be an appropriate intervention for decreasing physical aggression after determining the function to be attention?
quizquestion.explanation: Planned ignore is the most appropriate, function based, intervention out of the options provided. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following may be an appropriate intervention for decreasing physical aggression after determining the function to be getting out of school work?
quizquestion.explanation: Escape extinction is the most appropriate intervention that is function based out of the options provided. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: Mary engages in frequent elopement. You observe Mary and notice that this behavior typically occurs as soon as she is asked to complete a task at school. The teacher typically responds by telling Mary “it’s okay, we will work on this later”. What appears to be the contingency in place?
quizquestion.explanation: Socially mediated negative reinforcement is correct, because the teacher is permitting the escape. The removal of the school work demands increases the frequency of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: Mary engages in frequent elopement. You observe Mary and notice that this behavior typically occurs as soon as she is asked to complete a task at school. The teacher typically responds by telling Mary “it’s okay, we will work on this later”. What appears to be the function of Mary’s behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Mary is getting out of school work. This appears to be maintained by escape. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: Mary engages in frequent elopement. You observe Mary and notice that this behavior typically occurs as soon as she is asked to complete a task at school. The teacher typically responds by telling Mary “it’s okay, we will work on this later”. What might be a function based intervention for Mary?
quizquestion.explanation: Escape extinction is the most appropriate intervention that is function based out of the options provided. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: Thomas makes crude jokes frequently. You notice that most people laugh when he tells these jokes, increasing the likelihood that he will tell these jokes again. What contingency appears to be occurring?
quizquestion.explanation: This behavior is socially mediated (other people laughing) and is positive reinforcement, in that the addition of the stimulus (laughing) increases the likelihood of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)

quizquestion.question: Thomas makes crude jokes frequently. You notice that most people laugh when he tells these jokes, increasing the likelihood that he will tell these jokes again. What appears to be the function of this behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Attention (people laughing) appears to be the function of this behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 501-504)          {

quizquestion.question: Sara sees the color blue and says “blue.” Sara sees the color sky blue and says “blue”. Sara sees the color dark blue and says “blue”. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus generalization occurs when a different stimulus evokes the same response. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: You are teaching your child letters. You have taught it in a structured environment and now are working on identifying letters in different environments. When you are at the mall, you both see the letter “X” on the “Exit” sign. You point to it and ask the child “What letter do you see?”. The child says “X”. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus generalization occurs when a different stimulus evokes the same response. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: Sara is taught to write with her right hand. The next day, her teacher notices that she is writing with her left hand. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Response generalization occurs when a learner emits an untrained response which is functionally equivalent to the trained behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a learner emits an untrained response which is functionally equivalent to the trained behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Response generalization occurs when a learner emits an untrained response which is functionally equivalent to the trained behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: This occurs when a different stimulus evokes the same response.
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus generalization occurs when a different stimulus evokes the same response. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: Generalization is not always a good thing. Sometimes maladaptive behaviors may generalize to a new form or setting. The nontechnical term commonly used for this is:
quizquestion.explanation: Overgeneralization occurs when maladaptive behaviors generalize to a new form or setting. This is commonly used, but is not a technical term. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: The extent to which behavior occurs after the intervention has been removed refers to:
quizquestion.explanation: Response maintenance refers to behavior that occurs after the intervention has been removed. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: Mary is trained to give high 5’s by putting her hand out (palm up). She then gives a high 5 by putting her hand with palms facing outwards, without being trained to do so. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Response generalization occurs when a learner emits an untrained response which is functionally equivalent to the trained behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: Mary is trained to put her pants on by placing her left leg in, then her right leg in. Later, she is observed sitting down and putting both legs in the pants at the same time. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Response generalization occurs when a learner emits an untrained response which is functionally equivalent to the trained behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)

quizquestion.question: Mary is trained to put her pants on while in the clinic. Then, she is seen putting her pants on at home without training at home. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Stimulus generalization occurs when a different stimulus evokes the same response. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 615-622)          {

phase.name: Behavioral contrast, behavioral momentum, and matching law

quizquestion.question: Ms. Rachel is giving Tracy 5 minutes of tablet time for completing  each step of her doing laundry task analysis for a total of 30 minutes possible at the end of the school day. Tracy has been completing each step of her task analysis independently for 4 weeks. Tracy’s mom does not have a tablet at home, and Tracy has been noncompliant since this program began at school. What appears to be the issue?
wrongAnswer: Tracy is now only extrinsically motivated
Tracy has lost interest in the iPad as a reinforcer
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast is evident in that a program is occurring at school but not at home. Where the program is not being implemented, Tracy is noncompliant. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 337)

quizquestion.question: When change to an intervention in one setting changes the frequency in that setting, and the frequency changes in the opposite direction in the setting where the intervention remained unchanged. This phenomenon is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast occurs when change to an intervention in one setting changes the frequency in that setting, and the frequency changes in the opposite direction in the setting where the intervention remained unchanged. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 337)

quizquestion.question: Tracy is punished for cursing at school, which has resulted in a decrease in cursing at school. Behavioral contrast is said to occur in this situation of at home, where there is no punishment:
wrongAnswer: Cursing is replaced with a functionally equivalent behavior.
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral contrast occurs when change to an intervention in one setting changes the frequency in that setting, and the frequency changes in the opposite direction in the setting where the intervention remained unchanged. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 337)

quizquestion.question: Rate of responding is proportional to the rate of reinforcement received from each choice alternative. This is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: Matching law states that rate of responding is proportional to the rate of reinforcement received from each choice alternative. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 318)

quizquestion.question: The matching law is applicable with which schedule of reinforcement?
quizquestion.explanation: The matching law is applicable to concurrent schedules where two options are available at the same time. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 318)

quizquestion.question: John mows his neighbors’ lawns. Mrs. Green pays $15, Mrs. Red pays $10, and Mrs. Black pays $20. All lawns are the same size and require the same effort. John only has time to mow one lawn, according to the matching law, whose lawn will John mow?
quizquestion.explanation: Matching law states that rate of responding is proportional to the rate of reinforcement received from each choice alternative. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 318)

quizquestion.question: What is known as a metaphor to describe a rate of responding and its resistance to change following an alteration in reinforcement conditions?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral momentum is a metaphor to describe a rate of responding and its resistance to change following an alteration in reinforcement conditions. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 493)

quizquestion.question: The high-probability request sequence is based on which behavioral metaphor?
quizquestion.explanation: Behavioral momentum is a metaphor to describe a rate of responding and its resistance to change following an alteration in reinforcement conditions. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 493)

quizquestion.question: To conduct a high-probability request sequence, the learner starts by presenting 3-5:
quizquestion.explanation: The high-p request sequence is conducted by first presenting 3-5 high probability requests, then a low probability request. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 493)

quizquestion.question: Jeremy often refuses to brush his teeth. His father gives several requests Jeremy enjoys doing such as spinning in a circle, jumping, giving 5, etc. Jeremy is then asked to brush his teeth, and he complies. This procedure is known as:
quizquestion.explanation: The high-p request sequence is conducted by first presenting 3-5 high probability requests, then a low probability request. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 493)          {

quizquestion.question: You are told not to drink soda because it is unhealthy. You immediately stop drinking soda, even though you have never personally felt the negative side effects of drinking soda. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Rule-governed behavior is behavior that occurs as a result of a stated rule, without directly coming in to contact with the contingency. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: You are told not to drink soda because it is unhealthy. You immediately stop drinking soda, even though you have never personally felt the negative side effects of drinking soda. Being told about the negative effects of soda is a:
quizquestion.explanation: A rule is a verbal statement outlining a contingency, without requiring actual contact with the contingency. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: You drink soda every day. One day you choke on the soda and the frequency of that behavior decreases. This behavioral change is:
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency shaped behavior is controlled by temporally close consequences. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: This is a verbal statement outlining a contingency, without requiring actual contact with the contingency.
quizquestion.explanation: A rule is a verbal statement outlining a contingency, without requiring actual contact with the contingency. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: What type of behavior is controlled by temporally close consequences?
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency shaped behavior is controlled by temporally close consequences. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: What type of behavior is controlled by a verbal statement describing a contingency?
quizquestion.explanation: Rule-governed behavior is behavior that occurs as a result of a stated rule, without directly coming in to contact with the contingency. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: Even though he has never been in a car accident or received a ticket, John usually buckles his seat belt without being told every time he sits in a vehicle. John buckling his seat belt is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Rule-governed behavior is behavior that occurs as a result of a stated rule, without directly coming in to contact with the contingency. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: John rarely wore his seatbelt. Luckily he was wearing a seatbelt when he got in a car accident, and remained unharmed. From that day on John wore his seatbelt daily. John’s seatbelt wearing behavior appears to be:
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency shaped behavior is controlled by temporally close consequences. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: Mary has never smoked a cigarette because she is underage, and does not want to have legal problems. Mary’s behavior appears to be:
quizquestion.explanation: Rule-governed behavior is behavior that occurs as a result of a stated rule, without directly coming in to contact with the contingency. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)

quizquestion.question: Mary smokes cigarettes even though she is a minor. She is arrested and fined for this illegal behavior. Mary does not smoke again. Mary’s behavior appears to be:
quizquestion.explanation: Contingency shaped behavior is controlled by temporally close consequences. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 703)          {

quizquestion.question: Which verbal operant is a repeat of another speaker’s verbal behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic is the verbal operant which is a repeat of another speaker’s verbal behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: If I say “run” to a girl, this is a mand under which condition:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: There is a dog running toward the girl
wrongAnswer: The girl asked what my dog is doing
The girl said “run” and I was repeating her
The girl asked me what I like to do
quizquestion.explanation: The mand is a verbal operant where the speaker asks for what they “need”/”want”. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: If I say “run” to a girl, this is an echoic verbal operant under which condition?
wrongAnswer: There is a dog running toward the girl
The girl asked what my dog is doing
The girl asked me what I like to do
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic is the verbal operant which is a repeat of another speaker’s verbal behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: Which verbal operant is controlled by a motivating operation?
quizquestion.explanation: The Mand is a verbal operant which is controlled by a motivating operation. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: What does echoic behavior produce for the speaker?
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic behavior results in generalized conditioned reinforcement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: What is produced for the speaker as reinforcement for a mand?
quizquestion.explanation: The item requested is produced for the speaker following a mand. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: Mary says “duck” to her friend standing next to her. This is a mand if:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A Frisbee is flying toward Mary’s friend
wrongAnswer: The friend asked “Mary, what it is your favorite food?”
quizquestion.explanation: The Mand is a verbal operant which is controlled by a motivating operation. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: Mary says “duck” to her friend standing next to her. This is echoic behavior if:
wrongAnswer: A Frisbee is flying toward Mary’s friend
The friend asked “Mary, what it is your favorite food?”
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic is the verbal operant which is a repeat of another speaker’s verbal behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: Ally says “cookie”. This would be a mand if:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: It resulted in Ally getting a cookie
quizquestion.explanation: The item requested is produced for the speaker following a mand. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)

quizquestion.question: Ally says “cookie”. This would be echoic behavior if:
wrongAnswer: It resulted in Ally getting a cookie
quizquestion.explanation: Echoic is the verbal operant which is a repeat of another speaker’s verbal behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530)          {

quizquestion.question: The therapist is teaching verbal operant to a learner. She holds up a toy car with her hand and asks the learner “what is it?”. The learner says “car”. The therapist then provides the learner with a piece of cookie. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: The tact is a verbal operant in which the speaker names things they see, hear, feel, etc. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: On a field trip to the zoo, Lisa saw the sign to the petting area. Upon entering, a sheep walked by her. Lisa pointed and said “Sheep”. Lisa exhibited which verbal operant?
quizquestion.explanation: The tact is a verbal operant in which the speaker names things they see, hear, feel, etc. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: I ask my friend “where are your glasses?” And she responds “on the table”, this is an example of which verbs operant?
quizquestion.explanation: Intraverbal operants are evoked by a verbal SD and does not have point to point correspondence. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: Aliana is in the playground with her family. Suddenly, she sees a cat and says “cat.” Her mom says “good job, that is a cat.” This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: The tact is a verbal operant in which the speaker names things they see, hear, feel, etc. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: You are driving with your young child in the car. A firetruck drives by while you are at a red light. The child says “firetruck!”. This is an example of what type of verbal behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: The tact is a verbal operant in which the speaker names things they see, hear, feel, etc. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: Mary says “truck”. This would be a tact if:
wrongAnswer: Mary was asked what her favorite type of vehicle is
Mary is given a toy truck
quizquestion.explanation: The tact is a verbal operant in which the speaker names things they see, hear, feel, etc. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: Mary says “truck”. This would be an intraverbal operant if:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Mary was asked what her favorite type of vehicle is
wrongAnswer: Mary is given a toy truck
quizquestion.explanation: Intraverbal operants are evoked by a verbal SD and does not have point to point correspondence. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: John says “How old are you”, to which Phillip replies “22”. Phillip’s behavior is an example of a(n):
quizquestion.explanation: Intraverbal operants are evoked by a verbal SD and does not have point to point correspondence. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: Harold says “pizza”. This would be a tact if:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: A picture of a pizza was present.
wrongAnswer: Harold was asked “What’s your favorite food?”
quizquestion.explanation: The tact is a verbal operant in which the speaker names things they see, hear, feel, etc. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)

quizquestion.question: Harold says “pizza”. This would be an intraverbal operant if:
quizquestion.correctAnswer: Harold was asked “What’s your favorite food?”
wrongAnswer: A picture of a pizza was present.
quizquestion.explanation: Intraverbal operants are evoked by a verbal SD and does not have point to point correspondence. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 530-531)          {

quizquestion.question: The product of measurement is:
quizquestion.explanation: Data is the product of measurement. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 127)

quizquestion.question: The dead man test helps in identifying:
wrongAnswer: The environmental variables in the environment
quizquestion.explanation: The dead man’s test states that if a dead man can do it, it isn’t a behavior.

quizquestion.question: Which one is not a measurable dimension of behavior?
quizquestion.explanation: Topography is not a measurable dimension of behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 75)

quizquestion.question: Which dimension of behavior states that behavior occurs at a certain point in time?
quizquestion.explanation: Temporal locus states that behaviors occur at a certain point in time. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 75)

quizquestion.question: Which dimension of behavior states that behavior occurs during some amount of time.
quizquestion.explanation: Temporal extent states that behavior occurs during some amount of time. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 75)

quizquestion.question: Which dimension of behavior states that behavior can occur repeated through time, and can be counted.
quizquestion.explanation: Repeatability states that behavior can occur repeatedly through time. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 75)

quizquestion.question: John engaged in 3 angry outbursts per hour. Which measure is this an example of?
quizquestion.explanation: Rate is a measure that calculates the frequency of the behavior across time. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 75)

quizquestion.question: John engaged in an episode of angry outbursts for 3 minutes. This is an example of which measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Duration measures the amount of time a behavior occurs. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 75)

quizquestion.question: John engaged in an angry outburst 3 seconds after being prompted to complete a chore. This is an example of which measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Latency is the measure from the stimulus to the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 75)

quizquestion.question: John engaged in an angry outburst, then 3 seconds later engaged in another angry outburst. This is an example of which measure?
quizquestion.explanation: Inter Response Time refers to the amount of time between to occurrences of behavior.          {

phase.name: Advantages and disadvantages of using continuous and discontinuous measurement procedures

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is not a discontinuous measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording is a continuous measurement procedure. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: What is another name for discontinuous measurement procedures?
quizquestion.explanation: Time sampling (not to be confused with momentary time sampling) is another name for discontinuous measurement procedures. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following underestimates how often the behavior is occurring?
quizquestion.explanation: Whole interval recording underestimates the measure of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following overestimates how often the behavior occurs?
quizquestion.explanation: Partial interval recording overestimates the measure of the behavior. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: Jose engages in disruptive behaviors in class frequently. To measure this behavior you create measurement intervals and record a “yes” if he was disruptive during the ENTIRE session. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Whole interval recording records if the behavior occurred during the ENTIRE session. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: Jose engages in disruptive behaviors in class frequently. To measure this behavior you create measurement intervals and record a “yes” if he was disruptive at any time during the session. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Partial interval recording records if the behavior occurred at any time during the session. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: Jose engages in disruptive behaviors in class frequently. To measure this behavior you check on Jose once every 30 minutes and record if he was disruptive at that moment. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Momentary time sampling occurs by measuring if the behavior occurred at the end of an interval. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: Which of the following is a continuous measurement procedure?
quizquestion.explanation: Event recording is a continuous measurement procedure. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: Mary engages in hand flapping frequently, making it difficult to record this behavior. You create intervals, and document if the behavior occurred during the ENTIRE interval. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Whole interval recording records if the behavior occurred during the ENTIRE session. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)

quizquestion.question: Mary engages in hand flapping frequently, making it difficult to record this behavior. You create intervals and document “yes” if the behavior occurred at all during the session. This is an example of:
quizquestion.explanation: Partial interval recording records if the behavior occurred at any time during the session. (Cooper et al., 2007, p. 88-93)
